reviewText:
I regret buying this.  My initial assessment was that it seemed pretty good.  The gameplay quickly degrades however.  It seems like this game is trying to emulate games from the COD or Gears of War franchises.  This could be ok if it didn't seem like actual gameplay was an afterthought.  It's as if they designed these set pieces or scenarios and then thought about how to shovel in gameplay afterward.  The first realization of this was in the gun shop scene: WE ARE IN A GUN SHOP WHERE IS THE AMMO?!   I'd assume the owner wouldn't be so stingy because it's a zombie apocalypse, but perhaps I assume too much.

Ok, then aftewards Leon and Helena are on a bus where a big fat zombie is holding up the front tires so they can't get away.  They have to survive other zombies' attacks, while trying to emtpy enough rounds into the big one's head through the front window.  Zombies come into the bus, they melee them, they shoot the bus lifter, rinse, repeat.  It takes too long to get enough ammo to do this.  I'm ok with making a game challenging via ammo crunch, but this just breaks the tension and gets BORING.  Not to mention our big uberbadass Leon has a fatigue gauge where he can't kick a zombie if it runs out.  When we're surrounded by very dumb NPCs (who don't shoot the ranged spitter zombies) and trying to survive by doing super badass moves (more on that later) it was very frustrating to have this happen.  Game to player: give zombies running bulldogs and sweet roundhouse kicks!  Player:  Ok sure!! Game:  Oh wait we gotta be like all realistic and like the other big blockbuster games, so nm hobble around.  Oh also player, you can't keep like a shovel or 2 by 4 these guys try to attack you with to attack them back.. cuz like, we wanna kinda also be like old arcade games.  We'll just keep the worst of both worlds to make it frustrating.  Player: Damn this kind of sucks I hope the next encounter doesn't suck like this.

So that gets done and it gets to the cathedral.  This was like in Wolverine Origin when they get to the island.  The game is cruising along, not good, not bad, and then the wheels just fall right off.  First off, this church has security statues with laser guided crossbows.  I'm assuming it's some kind of facility b/c of what happened next... so why would they have an odd, inneffective security system of this style, instead of some kind of modern sentry turret, or ya know, a locked door.  So that part is also really dumb.  Then there's the boss fight where a zombie will pick up Leon and tentacle ♥♥♥♥ his face if you press buttons wrong.  This was the last straw for me.  I get that in games, especially horror games, your character will meet a grisly fate if you mess up.  The scene was just so gratuitously revolting.  It must have been included solely for a gross out, I guess.  Well I don't play games to be grossed out.  Again, shouldn't the gameplay be on the forefront of the designer's mind?  There was quickly a draught of ammo and melee did completely nothing to this boss while NPCs shot at nothing with their guns that apparently had infinite ammo.  Oh wait this boss also spews gas which turns people into zombies but Leon and Helena aren't affected, they can just stab each other in the heart with a syringe and then take herbs like mints and are fine.

So in a comparative summary:

Resident Evil 4 was 90 percent great and 10 percent manure (button mashing sequences and the block sliding puzzle should have been editted out on the re-release)

Resident Evil 5 is a little more on the manure side but that's still far outweighted by the good parts of game,  It has button mashing, but during one, the main character punches a boulder out of the way because he's just so damn jacked.

Resident Evil 6 starts off pretty good but quickly becomes a chore, but might appeal to those who value images of homesexual ♥♥♥♥ in a game over decent gameplay.

If it's a horror story with environement you're into, find something else and if it's action - again, find something else.  This doesn't combine them decently and both sides are weak.  Time sink" comes to mind on this thing with plenty of hunting around for ammo to fight.

reviewText:
Pro:
+ There's a co-op mode.
+ Surprisingly playable with a controller.

Con:
- There're needlessly long cutscenes every few minutes in the game, which you cannot skip.
- You can't even access the main menu without playing a 20 minutes long tutorial.
- You can not pause the game. Never ever. You have a phone call? Restart from the last checkpoint and watch the cutscene again.
- Ingame HUD popups (e.g. inventory, menu) have different keys for closing them. If you accidentally open one, you have to search for the correct key to close it and continue the game. While you're being attacked, of course.
- You can't attack bodies that lay around. Not until they start attacking you after you walked past them.
- You can't explore the maps, there's only one path from point A to point B that you must walk, and there's no chance to walk  up to any other door or corridor.

reviewText: Calling this a bad game is definetely a mistake, personally ISN'T the same as what any old RE used to feel like. Although complaining that this isn't survival horror is completely irrelevant as ever being done since RE4, there was NO survival horror labeled to this game. So why EXPECTING it. Calling it typical is very funny, there is no game like this out there, whatever they say. It has it's unique genre and way to display just like it's predecessors.  Innovation is when you make something different, not milk the same thing over and over. Resident Evil has for years always been a pleasure to play along, great characters just as the imagination for enemies. It keeps featuring more and more replayability every titles. For me, having to play the same style with a specific set of goals and predictable slow and barely harmful creatures is not my piece of favor. Having to remind of how they tried since REmake which IS after RE4 to create something that would be awesome to have in hands. This is the prime example, todays developper won't limit themselves to a static camera with simplistic controls. They'll go for what evolving calls, just like the players. Telling RE6 isn't scary is no excuses to call it bad, you got used to it and from my experience i did too. I'd rather have a series that became varied than be running around for the same puzzles everytimes i wanted to play it. Hell, even with REmake they had this features allowing to either create a vibe of freedom or a specific set of objectives, not forgetting to mention the very challenging hidden modes which NONE of the olders (Aside RE3) had before and there's RE6 right here coming with Mercs mode and much more with all of any possible thing to add so far. Either you pass or try to appreciate the unseen content of this quality sequel of a well known franchise for their bio-terrorist context. You don't remain scared forever by zombies, just like the characters themselves.

reviewText: very entertaining, Well executed, nice graphics and a fun campaign mode. However, controlling the characters with the keyboard, could be a mess...Use a gamepad/joystick for Windows. Exactly what you expect from Resident Evil , I must say that I love this game. I love the addition of four stories instead of the usual one story with three difficulties. Like RE5, there is a co-op option, which I do take advantage of, since AI's are useless in every way aside from healing you. There is more to try to achieve with this game, unlike the others. You can track your unlocked files, achievements and game progress. Each campaign has an interlocked story, but they each have different overall skill usage. Leon's campaign is more defense, since you can stay safe in most all boss battles by just keeping distance of rolling on the ground. Jake's campaign is more melee, since there are parts of the game that you can only use Sherry's stun rod and Jake's hands to fight, they also don't give you a lot of ammo in this campaign. Chris is more firearm attacks, since they give you enemy after enemy that can't be taken down easily and they give you enough bullets that you'll have to shoot to make noise to keep room in your inventory. Ada's is mainly puzzles and quick thinking, since a few parts of the game are a race against time, and if you so much as run into a wall for too long of a second, you die. This was an excellent addition to the game, so it doesn't feel like the chapters and campaigns all run together. All over, this was a very great purchase. The game is a clean and easy install with no patches required for full function. The graphics are amazing. I have this on a Windows 7 x64 system .

reviewText:
★ = Poor
★★ = Fair
★★★ = Good
★★★★ = Nice
★★★★★ = Awesome ✔

Heard quite a lot of bad reviews for this game. Don't see why is it so bad. Is it because you can't kick noob players? Your Campaign story suddenly turn into a versus game?

First of all, why are you even playing it with strangers? If you don't want to play it with strangers, why not disable the co-op option in the first place?
Sudden unwanted Agent Hunt invasion? Why did you even enable Agent Hunt when you don't want it?

I know Resident Evil changed a lot, it's not like what it used to be, it's becoming more of an action game. But I don't really care whether it's an action game or a horror survival game, I'm here for the storyline and I really like it a lot.
I like how the loss of accuracy after aiming for too long or firing a shot.
No weapon upgrades anymore meaning no more overpowered weapons.
No more annoying cut scene QTEs.
Four different Campaign with unique storyline which are linked to each other.
Playable infected characters.
Ability to perform melee attacks and dodges with free will.
Ability to move around while aiming.

For those who don't like it, I have to say this is not the game for you and I really feel sorry for you to have wasted your parent's money.

reviewText: Even though this is probably the best PC port Capcom has ever done I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone unless you're a huge fan of RE series. Too many cut-scenes and action cut-scenes, camera acts unpredictably sometimes and some boss battles are unnecessary hard even on easier difficulty levels. On the bright side the game is really long (around 20 hours) which isn't common for action games these days. In overall they could do it so much better but failed. 7 out of 10.

reviewText: Overlong and overstuffed, RE6 still boasts the best gameplay of the series to-date.  It's an action game through and through, like it or not, but it's a pretty damn good one.  The Quick-shot is one of the best unnoticed mechanics of all time, and would add a lot to similar 3rd person action games.  Hugely flawed, of course, but most giant, ambitious projects are.

reviewText: Resident evil 6 is a very good third person shooter game. i can tell you its definitly not a generic shooter game. killing the enemies does not get boring very quickly and the levels are everything but forgetable unlike actual generic shooter games. the game of course does have its negative aspects like the most obvious one, its not a horror game . the lack of weapon costumisation, changing and upgrading can be very annoying sometimes. there arent much of boss battles like previous resident evil games. and the camera can be very klaustrophobic sometimes. but i PERSONNALY think the removage of the tank controlls is a god gift. the ability to melee, counter, dodge, walk whule aiming, dashing at any time is more then just helpfull.the amount of enemies is also very neat. there is a huge amount of differences in enemies from the normal classic zombies. tougher zombies bloodshots (wich are waay to easy to counter BTW) to the new kind of enemies like ganados wich appeared the first time in RE4 also known as j'avo and their very many different mutations. every different enemies needs a different way to kill it wich is like a minigame for each one.the story is a little luckluster. since its pretty much just some rich snob wants to F*ck ada.but the story can be ignored because its not getting shoved down your throw like other game wich i want name here. i dont like the inventory system of this game. i think RE4 & RE5 did a much better modern inventory. i really dont like the fact that you can have all weapons at once. not choose wich ones you want like older RE games.but yeah in overall. this game is not perfect and oh boy how it sucks for being a resident evil game. but its alot i mean ALOT of fun. with a very high replay value. i recommend it to everyone who likes TPS or atleast loves the resi characters.its not even close as good as RE6. but it IS better then RE5. good game. not perfect. but good

reviewText: В независимости от того, что эту игру успели обругать, я скажу иное. Меня больше всего впечатлил список компаний (того гляди Отдельных игр, собранных вместе), так вот, их 4: За Леона, Криса, Аду и Джейка (нового персонажа). Компании Огромны, поэтому игру проходить долго, что я и не сделал до сих пор. Краски больно тёмные, везде ночь, зомби хорошие, много типов. Порадовал режим игры за зомби, где нужно другим игрокам проходить игру, хотя и зомби очень медленные. Есть выживание - отстрел зомби, конечно же за награды. В каждой кампании есть напарник, и теперь уже и в кампании Ады на ПК (На других консолях у неё нет напарника). Итак, игра хорошая (8/10).

reviewText: This game is considered to be the worst main story of the franchise, it is true that it is not at all as scary as the older games were, but that doesn't mean it is a bad game. Graphics are decent, characters are interesting, Ada's campaign is just great and if you do this multiplayer it is just awesome. I would recommend this to people that just want to have fun smashing in zombie heads, and if you have a friend then go ahead and smash them together, but don't compare it to the other games as it really doesn't fit in with the style, it's a blast in its own way.

reviewText:
So, what can I say about this game? It's a modern Resident Evil title. It took a few good things from Revelations 1, one nice thing from the old titles and a lot of bad stuff from a lot of other Resi titles. But I'm getting ahead of myself.
If you want to skip the lengthy part of my review, you can find the pros and cons list below.

First things first: the story.
The story is a bit bigger this time around. For one thing, it's because of the fact that it features five campaigns. On the other hand it's because this time the story centers around the fate of the world - AGAIN! Well. But it doesn't feel as insignificant as Revelations 1 since you'll be fighting against a lot of ♥♥♥♥ in the USA, China, Edonia and other places. An organization by the name of Neo Umbrella has risen and is terrorizing the world with... well... bioterrorism. Like in all the other games. But the game looks better than its predessecors. So that's a plus. Anyway. The main character cast centers around Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Sherry Birkin, Ada Wong along with their respective sidekicks. Also there's Albert Wesker's son but I won't spoiler anything. These people are trying to save the day by defeating Neo Umbrella. That's more or less the gist of it.

Fans of the old games will be pleased to hear that you'll be fighting classic zombies from time to time. When you first start the game with Leon you'll be watching limping half-corpses around a city in the USA and when you're in China you'll be seeing them there, too. On enemy variety the devs were pretty creative again. But nothing too new tbh. You got the classic zombies, you got the J'avo. The J'avo are somewhat like the Majini and Ganados, only more extreme and instead of a parasite there's a virus responsible for their mutations. The J'avo have some surprises up their sleeve when it comes to mutations so that's not all too bad. These are the main enemy types. But the bosses are where it's really at. Remember El Gignte? You'll be fighting a couple of those in this game (not like the farce of an El Gigante in RE 5). Then there's a bunch of hulking creatures of plates and muscle with are ♥♥♥♥ing annyoing to defeat because they're bullet sponges. And some other boss battles with a giant, invisible snake, crazy people who thought injecting a dose of the virus into themselves was a good idea (didn't see THAT one coming *chuckles*) and some other ♥♥♥♥ I don't wanna spoiler.

But wherever there's an enemy, there oughtta be a weapon to defeat it, right? Yes! Weapons wise there's a lot. In every campaign you'll be getting different weapons and every character you play as has a different set of starting weapons to begin with. Over the course of each campaign you'll acquire new weapons and you will find a lot of uses for each of them. And yes, there's an elephant killer magnum gun again. But as always, it's ♥♥♥♥ing hard to find any ammo for this thing so hear my advice and use it in boss battles or if absolutely nessecary. Like when you'll be fighting against those chainsaw ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (that are EVEN harder to kill this time around). Aside from that there's a bunch of stationary weapons and some are one time use only.
But the best part about this is: in theory you don't even need weapons most of the time because they finally improved the melee combat. meaning that you can now punch and kick your way through  hordes of enemies. Given that they don't shoot you down. Warning: not recommended on harder difficulties because it's generally a dumb idea to only do melee fighting in any Resi game. Well, usually if you have to do that you're bsaically screwed and might as well start over. In this one you can deal considerable damage to your enemies with melee combat. Which is a plus. Also the animation set for melee combat is quite nice to look at.

On the technical side of things the game runs fine on highest setting, no FPS drops, no crashes. Only one time it didn't recognize my save file but that problem was quickly sorted out so fear not, you won't have any technical issues with this one. At least I didn't have any.
Game mechanics wise there's a lot of stuff I didn't like and some stuff I was really fond of. As I mentioned earlier, there's half-decent melee combat now, which is a plus. Then you may move while aiming and shooting. First Resi game that brought that one to us was Revelations 1, I believe. Which is a great plus. They finally noticed just how useful this feature is. Knife fighting is no more, you instead screw 'em with your guns in melee combat. Also a good idea. What else? Well, you can walk, run, shoot, hit, die, survive, climb, jump down (a lot of these actions may require you to stand at specific positions however. Resi style) and, when playing with Ada, use your grappling hook.
Oh and there's skills now. Like, you collect skill points and after each chapter or so you can buy and upgrade skills with them. The idea's nice but ultimately useless as I didn't use them all that often. Only scenario where I could imagine them being useful would be on the really high difficulties that aren't even fun anymore.
Also the partner mechanic is back but it isn't annyoing anymore. Now enemies target your partner too (not like RER) and you almost never have to worry about them dying (unlike RE5).
Aside from that it's standard 3rd Person Shooter. Oh, but wait!
They are back. More gloriously than ever before. They Q to the T to the E. QTE sections en masse with this game. I mean, I can understand it having a few QTEs in the game. But in Resi 6 they are pretty much used excessively. Not as bad as most of the reception is putting it but it's not like they had any QTEs left after this one. There are a lot of scenes where you just have to smash a few buttons to come forward and avoid death. At least some of the QTEs are creative in the sense that they require you to click at a specific time. But yeah, they're still QTEs.

What else?
I got a few gripes with this game QTE wise, yeah. But the worst part is that the credits are unskippable. That wouldn't be so bad if:
The credits weren't so long because a trillion people worked on this game and
you wouldn't have to watch them five times.
Why five times? Well, there are five campaigns and after completing each campaign you are required to watch those unskippable, long-♥♥♥ credits.

And the final piece of information will be the subtle humour in the game which is most prevalent in Jake's campaign because Jake is just the badass guy who doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about most of it and just does his thing along with his audible drek. It's funny, really. Mostly anyway.

So, to wrap this up, pros and cons!

Pros:
+ Improved graphics
+ The story isn't too bad (and feels WAY more significant than RER's)
+ Most of the mechanics in the game are improved
+ Different animation sets for a lot of enemies (not unlike some OTHER games. Yeah RE5, I'm lookin' at you)
+ Oldschool zombie slashing action in the first few hours of the game bringing back good memories
+ Awesome death scenes. Seriously, to die in this game can look pretty cool. There's even an achievement for that
+ Fairly good melee combat and gunplay
+ Ludicrous bosses that are even more crazy than before (I like that stuff)
+ Good enemy variety
+ NO QTEs IN CUTSCENES
+ Replayability because you can choose between two characters playing a campaign and each of them is a different approach
+ And more

Cons!
- A thousand QTEs
- Unskippable credits
- Linear gameplay and story (as always)
- Horror? Lol, no
- Boring puzzles"
- You'll die frequently because of some QTEs
- I got nothing more honestly

Would I recommend this game? Yeah
date: it's good for what it does.\nAt 20 bucks? Maybe think about it. If you're a hardcore Resi fan then yes
recommended: if you just like 3rd person shooters wait for a sale."
hoursPlayed: February 8, 2015

reviewText: I played enough of this game to recommend it to you. There's everything to love and nothing to hate. If we consider the last trilogy, Resident Evil from 4 to 6 this is easily the best of them all, the culmination of the action Capcom offers. You can do all sort of new moves which are awesome, you can slide, dodge, land on your back and shoot from the ground (which can be done when enemies drop you too), you can fight in melee with combos or switching to a melee weapon. I really like the fluidity of the game and it's even more fun with a friend. The coop of this game is great, you are not helpless per sé, you can counter enemies' grapples, you can even stand up" for yourself if you survive long enough in a down state

reviewText:
If you actually forget the fact that Resident Evil is a horror game and classify it as an action game this is actually pretty damn good. The focus is really heavy on getting quick kills with powerful melee finishers and the counter insta kill mechanic is a huge plus (something similar to Jill's counter evasions in 3 but more obvious).

If you find that the game isn't survival'esq enough go with no hope difficulty, if you're just starting the series then go with Veteran or Professional. There's no need to play normal or easy.

The story of 6 is told through 4 viewpoints; Leon+Helena, Chris+Piers, Sherry+Jake and Ada. Each one overlaps with another at some point in time and those outcomes will switch to force the characters your playing as to play the major role.

While the single player can be fun I think the major focus here is in the multiplayer, I've never been too big on playing mercenaries other than to just unlock stuff but with the new mechanics it really grabs your focus. All the other competitive" style multi modes are all DLCs and it's a hit or miss if you buy them
date: although I hear survivors is the most played (DM/TDM).\n\nIf you just remember that you're playing an action game
recommended: it's pretty good. Don't have high expectations of this being a puzzle heavy surv horror and you can appreciate what it is."

reviewText:
The Resident Evil 6 series was great. It's an intense game, where you can play as Leon, Helena, Chris, Piers, Jake, or Sherry. The three main campaigns (Leon, Chris, Jake), link up as they progress. (Helena, Piers, and Sherry are side characters that you can play as.) Every campaign has it's own unique story line - although they're linked. Leon, with zombies, and a few mutants. Chris was Javo, muscular zombie-like men with guns, and a huge muscular lion-like creature covered in solid. And Jake, a Hand-To-Hand expert, with huge zombies, such as Ustanak.
Each character has their own unique styles, Leon/Chris perfer long-mid range combat; Jake can get up close and personal using his bare hands, with martial arts. A virus breaks out, causing the United States to collapse. Would reccomend, although online isn't alive much; it's very fun.
Pros:
Kill monsters.
Scavange for ammo.
Small thrills in horror.
Amazing graphic style.
Amazing Counter-Attacks, follow ups, and fatalities."

Cons:
Little horror.
Occasional bugs that can insta-kill you in the story.
Several annoying QTE's (Quick-Time Events.)


Overall
date: I think it's an amazing game. Would reccomend."

reviewText: RE6 is a lot of fun. I was very pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed playing through the game. After RE5 I was ready to write off the series, but this corrects the course (mostly) for the franchise. It's like a big dumb summer action movie that never gives you time to catch your breath. This is definitely a newer, faster-paced RE even with the clunky controls. There are parts that harken back to the old school actually scary RE games where I'm collecting keys, I'm solving puzzles and it made me sad for that fantastic style is all but extinct these days. Action games are a dime a dozen, but a good horror game is something special. However, I gotta say, there's just something really cool about getting into fist fights with huge mutant monsters. There's always something getting shot, punched, stabbed, burned, blown up or crushed. This game has a lot of 'that was just cool' moments. My favorite was when one of the monsters gets run over by a school bus. There's four separate intertwined campaigns that take over 20 hours to finish the first time. The game is highly replayable. The story was utter nonsense, of course, but it was fun re-playing events from different perspectives. There's also a horde mode where the L4D2 crew are all playable characters. That was fun to see them in newer, spiffier graphics up to their old tricks, kicking zombie ♥♥♥. There's even a few special infected along for the ride. I heartily recommend RE6!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Don't let my hours distract you, I've played plenty of this game on my Xbox 360 and finally decided to step up to pc. The optimization in this game is amazing, It runs smooth and looks great, definately a step up from the Xbox 360 version. Although this game is very different then the previous installments in the series, it is definately an improvement in many categories, although the game did inherit the use of explosions similar to a Michael Bay film, and begin to ditch survival horror for action it still remains a fun and interesting game that any fan of the resident evil series should try.  For any newcomers to the series this game is great too, it is easy to pickup at times and at other times a bit difficult. I recommend when playing this game to try it on a more challenging difficulty, the game is too easy on lower difficulties and really challenging on the max difficulty. You will enjoy it.

The real improvement is that you can now walk and shoot and roll around like a mad man, it's amazing, a resident evil game where you are now limber and agile.

reviewText: While RE6 is definitely different from its predecessors, it is still a ride to hell. No Hope difficulty was a bit of a let down, for I was hoping for more of a Dark Souls type challenge, but its still a really fun game. Great Story, better voice acting than ANY of the previous titles in the franchise. With so many different ways to play, Leon, Helena, Chris, Piers, Jake, Sherry, and Ada, and each with similar yet different storys than intertwine together into a spiderweb-esque fashion (Kinda like the title screen I might add....thou im pretty sure I never saw a spider in the entire game.....strange, but something to look out for yourself to prove me wrong.), leave you never wanting to stop. I prefered playing the off characters to the main trio thou, they have different weapons...and not to spoil anything but Piers has a cool weapon you dont want to miss out on :P anyway, I would rate Resident Evil 6,  88/100

reviewText: RE6 is a lot of fun. I was very pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed playing through the game. After RE5 I was ready to write off the series, but this corrects the course (mostly) for the franchise. It's like a big dumb summer action movie that never gives you time to catch your breath. This is definitely a newer, faster-paced RE even with the clunky controls. There are parts that harken back to the old school actually scary RE games where I'm collecting keys, I'm solving puzzles and it made me sad for that fantastic style is all but extinct these days. Action games are a dime a dozen, but a good horror game is something special. However, I gotta say, there's just something really cool about getting into fist fights with huge mutant monsters. There's always something getting shot, punched, stabbed, burned, blown up or crushed. This game has a lot of 'that was just cool' moments. My favorite was when one of the monsters gets run over by a school bus. There's four separate intertwined campaigns that take over 20 hours to finish the first time. The game is highly replayable. The story was utter nonsense, of course, but it was fun re-playing events from different perspectives. There's also a horde mode where the L4D2 crew are all playable characters. That was fun to see them in newer, spiffier graphics up to their old tricks, kicking zombie ♥♥♥. There's even a few special infected along for the ride. I heartily recommend RE6!

reviewText: I was so put off from buying this game after reading every review i could find and finally i did buy it for the xbox and played through it twice and now ive bought it again on steam and wow oh wow what a game, it isnt my favourate RE game but ♥♥♥♥ it is fun and had so really enjoyable moments and great boss fights. I can see why people are so upset with this game i feel they just tried to add to much and try to many different things at once and in the end was to over the top for a RE game but once you can overlook certain aspects about the game it will offer you ALOT of fun and enjoyment. and one last note aobut the QTE's they are no where near as bad as i thoguht they were going to be, the only time they ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off was when a zombie gets to close to you and instantly throws you into a QTE that ♥♥♥♥ pissed me off ALOT

reviewText: Resident Evil 6 is the current latest numbered-entry in the long-running action-game series from Capcom. RE series (Resident Evil) has been evolving & moving further away from its survival-horror roots and more so into action-game territory with each entry - and in many people's opinions, this has been ringing more & more true with every entry since RE4. Regardless of what you may think of the changes in direction, there's one question still lingering: as a game, whatever it may be, is RE6 actually any good?\n\nTo answer the above question, one must also ask this: what does one actually want out a Resident Evil game? Do you want that Resident Evil 4 & 5 level of awesome action-packed gameplay and style? Leon's campaign certainly delivers this - and I think is the best overall campaign in the game; especially in the gameplay department. Leon's campaign is nothing short of awesome. Are you looking for an action-packed shooter-game w/ that bro-feel" w/ lots of soldiers (that are AI) often surrounding you and often comes across feeling like Call of Duty and Gears of War games often does? RE6 has that - and it has its own twist on that

reviewText: В независимости от того, что эту игру успели обругать, я скажу иное. reviewText:
Long time RE fan here (RE1 on PSX )! It was very hard for me to hit the recommend button for this game, and there are basically only three reasons why I am recommending it.

1: It does offer a lot of content. This has four normal sized campaigns, even if some of them have a couple of interlapping scenes, it will offer you plenty of hours of playing.

2: With a good co-op friend this game can be extremely fun. People give these modern RE's a hard time because of the less survival horror, or the fact that they are co-op, but I think co-op is actually one of the series biggests strenghts now. In a world with very few co-op games, this game is a fun time if you have some good friends to play it with. I highly recommend playing on the higher difficulties.

3: It's the Resident Evil universe. It's more of an already cool universe with enjoyable monsters and enjoyable characters. Yeah it's not perfect but it's still more RE.

Now what do I not like about this game? The controls take awhile to get used to, I don't know why, but they just feel more awkward than even the older titles. I think pair that with the extremely tight corridors in some of the campaigns and it just makes it feel extremely sloppy.

While the stories aren't bad, I felt there wasn't a good protagonist on the level of Wesker. I did like Chris's target for the first half, but although there was build up it did not end the way you would expect.

Leon's story I felt had the most boring / easy monsters, as well as the least inspired easy boss fights. I feel like Chris's campaign was just better over all.

Then you have some minor nit-picks on things that they took steps backwards from RE5. No DirectX10 support, no LAN support, and over all I'd say RE5 even looked better. The share system for swapping items is gone, and unless someone tells you picking the setting as the host doesn't actually change the other persons difficulty setting.

I think what disappointed me the most is that RE5 was basically a better game in every way. The only thing RE6 had going for it was length, but length is not important when RE5 just has more replay value. I think because I enjoyed RE5 so much more as a co-op game I will always just feel RE6 was one of the biggest let downs in the series. Don't get me wrong I still enjoyed it enough to recommend it, but barely.

reviewText:
If you actually forget the fact that Resident Evil is a horror game and classify it as an action game this is actually pretty damn good. The focus is really heavy on getting quick kills with powerful melee finishers and the counter insta kill mechanic is a huge plus (something similar to Jill's counter evasions in 3 but more obvious).

If you find that the game isn't survival'esq enough go with no hope difficulty, if you're just starting the series then go with Veteran or Professional. There's no need to play normal or easy.

The story of 6 is told through 4 viewpoints; Leon+Helena, Chris+Piers, Sherry+Jake and Ada. Each one overlaps with another at some point in time and those outcomes will switch to force the characters your playing as to play the major role.

While the single player can be fun I think the major focus here is in the multiplayer, I've never been too big on playing mercenaries other than to just unlock stuff but with the new mechanics it really grabs your focus. All the other competitive" style multi modes are all DLCs and it's a hit or miss if you buy them
date: although I hear survivors is the most played (DM/TDM).\n\nIf you just remember that you're playing an action game
recommended: it's pretty good. Don't have high expectations of this being a puzzle heavy surv horror and you can appreciate what it is."

reviewText: Am a huge fan of RE franchise, and I simply don't understand why people hated this game. Yeah honestly game evolves from puzzle soving type of genre into a shooter game and later into an action one where u roll, do counterattacks and so on. Although it's a really big change overall, I found this game really enjoyable, if you are thinking about buying it, it is worth it the try, you can always refund anyway, but I don't think there will be a reason for doing so. The only thing you should consider is that it is a next shooter, not the original RE game, many old gamers tend to stop playing RE games just because of that, so, if u are the veteran RE type person, there is a chance that u won't like this game, although I liked this change and I love the game, that decision will be up to you. And shortly to the story, you've got 3 main campaign, including famous character such as Leon S. Kennedy or Chris Redfield, + one smaller campaign including Ada Wong. I like the plot and everything around it as always, and the thing that they actually met in the game is just briliant for me, I love it all the way. So yeah this game for me is 8-8.5/10, just because it's again a new genre which developers have jumped into, although I recomend this game, everybody who loves RE should play this, no matter if the person prefers Shooter game or the puzzle game.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 is the latest intallment to the series. The first time I played RE6 I thought, wow, this game feels allot different then the other RE games, like the combat, camera angles, and story telling; Even though the game is different from the rest, that doesn't mean that the game is better; Change is not always a good thing.

Combat: The devs wanted to make a game that was more fast pace, and more appealing to new players in RE6; But by doing that they took away so much of what made the games so great. Resident Evil 6 feels more like an action game then a survival game now. one of the reasons the other games are so great is because of the combat system, you really had to think about what you were doing, and you conserve lots of ammo, and strategize allot, about where to shoot them, and what zombies to kill. But in RE6 the combat is way to easy, you can go in, run and gun with no consequence's at all.

Camera Angles: I can safely say that, the camera angles in RE6...SUCK! The angles of the camera is centered on the screen, and the guy is way too close to the screen; It is really heard to see around the guy. The only time you can really see good is if you ADS then the camera will center over the guys soldier, like the other resident evil games.

Story Telling: In past games there were one story in the game, but in RE6 there are 4 story's! And all the story's feel like they were half ♥♥♥'d. The only good campaign was Leon's Story, all the other stories had some cool sequences, but with out any spoilers, Leon's Campaign had the most going for it.

The Verdic: I did enjoy playing Leon's campaign but all the other campaigns felt extremely half ♥♥♥'d. The camera angles were extremely annoying in places, and the combat was way too fast paced. The only game mode that is really good with the combat system is the Mercenaries, especially the No Mercy Mercenaries.

Well I just gave you my honest opinion about the game.
I hope this review helpes you decide.

This is Death Wish Signing off.

reviewText:
Ok so lets get the Elephant in the room out of the way...

Alot of reviews have said `Well its not Resldent Evil really is it...`. Well that is utter tripe. It is a logical continuation of the RE  franchise.Sure it isn't classic Survival Horror but that has been done countless times in the series and things need to move on.

I for one would not want another game stuck with the frankly horrid and awkward controls we have been saddled with since RE:1. People do not rotate on the spot, neither are they incabable of walking and shooting and it's about time that convention died a sad and lonely death.

This is a good game and has plenty of old and new characters meeting across intersecting story lines. So far I have played Ada's campaign and had a blast. There are plenty of secrets to find, icky things to shoot and the odd classic `makes zero sense` puzzle thrown in.

There is a ton of Co-op, Versus and Online action to be had across the various DLC packs and plenty of replay value.

That is the pros out of the way, sadly there are a few cons you should be aware of:

There are more Quicktime events than in the Tomb Raider reboot and that is really saying something. I personally HATE QTE's and just wish programmers would sod off putting them in games already. My percentage scores for Ada's campaign is tragically low due to the amount of times I died because I failed yet another QTE mini `game`. Games are fun, QTE mini games are not.

I can handle dying because I played like an eejit and ran out of Ammo or walked into an obvious Ambush but failing to waggle the joystick, press X at a specific time then hit RT in the right order at the right speed is annoying beyond beleif.

The Controls are way better than previous iterations and being able to run and shoot is a godsend. However  there are ALOT of contextual actions and sometimes things go a bit wonky and you end up running into an enemy rather than actually pulling off some awesome takedown.

Other than those negatives this is definitely worth your time and money if you have any love for the RE series in particular or action games in General.

reviewText:
Don't let my hours distract you, I've played plenty of this game on my Xbox 360 and finally decided to step up to pc. The optimization in this game is amazing, It runs smooth and looks great, definately a step up from the Xbox 360 version. Although this game is very different then the previous installments in the series, it is definately an improvement in many categories, although the game did inherit the use of explosions similar to a Michael Bay film, and begin to ditch survival horror for action it still remains a fun and interesting game that any fan of the resident evil series should try.  For any newcomers to the series this game is great too, it is easy to pickup at times and at other times a bit difficult. I recommend when playing this game to try it on a more challenging difficulty, the game is too easy on lower difficulties and really challenging on the max difficulty. You will enjoy it.

The real improvement is that you can now walk and shoot and roll around like a mad man, it's amazing, a resident evil game where you are now limber and agile.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 has a really big change as compared to Resident Evil 5 in terms of gameplay and control performance. The most noticable features is the multiple character selection and different campaign routes. Below will be a list of pro's and con's that I've summarized from my experience with this game.

Proz:
1. Chargin' strike! Melee isn't just standing on the spot and doing a slash that is literally face to face.
2. Execution from melee combo! This was from RE4 but was somehow removed from RE5 so I'm really glad it's here!
3. Characters. Each character has their style of attacking so have fun exploring them all!
4. Serpent emblems are bigger, and more easily spotted throughout the campaign.
5. Vehicles isn't just limited to cars anymore.
6. Dodging buttons. Many others say this feature is useless but I think it's kinda useful for doing side rolls through vents.

Cons:
1. No more weapon upgrade feature or portable gatling guns :(
2. Herbs are incredibly rare after Chapter 1 of any campaign.
3. Camera angle in certain zones. Experienced RE players will know the struggle.
4. Online community is pretty much dead. Either that or there'll be some rushing jokers with a lifespan of 6 seconds speeding through the game.
5. Inventory is a joke. I understand that for story's sake, each character will not have a shared bank system like RE5 but this is the main contributing reason why I'm stopping every now and then because I have to choose between herbs or ammunition. If Christ can stuff an entire grenade launcher AND a sniper rifle in his pocket, why can't he do the same for the rest??!?
6. 8 skill slots and only 3 skills for each. You can only select one slot at a time. I strongly don't see why anyone would need up to 8 slots.

Overall rating from me would be 7/10. It's a good game that you won't regret. Long hours of gameplay and the unexpected QTE's are the fun" features of the game."

reviewText:
To-Long-Didn't-Read: Resident 6 PC May have problems, but It is a varied and enjoyable experience for fans of the action-oriented takes of RE4 and RE5. For the most enjoyable experience, play on veteran or professional.


I don't really understand why this game gets sh** on so much. I've been a fan of the Resident evil series since its inception, and have had to grit my teeth along with the rest of the fans through the movies and games like Raccoon City. Resident evil 6 may be flawed, but the PC version is a true successor to RE5, let me explain.

Many people's main complaints about RE6 are either the bad AI, the muddy graphics, or that it is a poor console port. Anyone who has played RE5 recently will recall just how bad the AI was in that game. Playing single player would mean that you would have to call Sheva 5 or 6 times to get her to help you open doors or do objectives. Sheva would constantly get knocked down or held in place, and she would knock you down with her attack reaction. The zombie AI in 5 was also pretty terrible, where J'avo would climb up things and then immediately jump off in order to attack you, or they would get stuck inside each other because they wouldn't understand where to go. In RE6, I feel like I never have to worry about my AI partner, and the enemy AI always keeps me on my toes(on Professional difficulty) with their new running leaps and ground grabs, and the large numbers of regular zombies make them feel actually threatening.

Though the graphics/ textures may be muddy at times even on the highest settings, the shaders and effects are great. and the underwater effects in Ada's campaign may be some of the best I've ever seen in a video game. That being said, there's not much of a graphical change from consoles to the PC version. Whats also important to realize though, is that Capcom has tried very hard to rectify their mistakes from the console versions, and has added tons of new options that will help tweak the game play to your preferences.

The story is in a similar vain to the RE5 story, where it's mostly action, losts of Quick-time, and some exploration. This time around, there are 4 campaigns, and though they may be shorter than RE5's full campaign, they keep the action varied and prevent it from becoming stale. Unfortunately, the action-oriented nature of the campaign seems to confuse some players, as if they forgot how much action/Quick-time that RE5 brought to the table.

The difficulty this time around has really increased. I vividly remember RE5's Professional difficulty being somewhat of a pushover, with zombie's movements and attacks being perfectly telegraphed and predictable. This time, Professional mode really increases the survival horror feel, as being grabbed or missing a dodge can spell death for your character. As I mentioned before, zombies have new attacks like running jumps and crawling grabs, and the special zombies can ruin your day quite easily.

All and all, the game is the next evolution of the RE series, which in my opinion is a great installment (we should be thankful they didn't continue to go the Raccoon City route). The new crossover instances and Agent attack modes can be fun, and are great ideas that I hope they continue with in the next installment.

9/10

reviewText:
Resident evil. A popular name in movies and games... This game gave me both a fright, a rush and a serious headache...
(this is the first RE game i've played, but I did look into the earlier releases)

The gist:

Pros  - Fun, refreshing combat (at times)
- Very interesting story arc
- 4 different perspectives on the campaign to play through, each with 2 characters to choose from
- Big variety of enemies and weapons (surprisingly)
- A very decent port to PC from console

Cons - A port from console to PC
- Stereotypical Japanese intensity and overreacting character personalities...
- It is either really easy, or frustratingly unfair
- Annoying as f**k cinematics and animations
- Really stupid design choices
- Did not come with contact details of the developers, so I can punch them all in their faces

The big one:

The biggest and most glaring issue with this game are the forced in-game cinematics you HAVE to watch every time your partner opens a path way (that I can clearly see is opening), or calls a switch to my attention or ties his shoe...

Many many times these cinematics led to my death because the enemies continue to attack you while you stand there watching the camera show you the inside of a tunnel for 30 seconds...



The explanation:

The design choices really irk me badly. From the attempted phone/PDA style menu that does not pause the game to the entire idea of releasing the RE series for consoles primarily is something I don't understand. Though having a game like this on console seems like the better choice it really isn’t.

I say this because the combat focuses heavily on the player to precisely hit limbs or the head of an enemy if you want to be ammo effective on harder difficulty settings. I tried playing with the Xbox controller for PC, but I always felt out of control and slow.

There are a lot of bad choices ranging from map design to camera angles but In all honesty, those bad choices are not stopping me from playing through the entire game... Because it is interesting and fun.


I can't tell you whether this is a better RE than the previous ones but what I can say, is that it is fun, cheap and a bulky amount of story to uncover and take part in...

reviewText:
***I'd like to preface this by saying I'm a HUGE old-school RE fan with a particular affinity to the REmake and RE: Code Veronica. I am about 12 hours into RE6 and havn't finished it yet***

I skipped RE6 when it came out because of how crushingly disappointed I was with RE5. After seeing the review scores, I pretty much figured I knew exactly the kind of terrible the game would be.

Fast forward to a couple days ago, it pops up on the Steam sale for $10, I pulled the trigger just to suffer through the game to see how batshit crazy the story has gotten. What I actually got was one of the most refreshingly playable Japanese-style shooters since Vanquish and Binary Domain. Let's put all the hub-bub aside, as a game with no strings attached; this game has great, tight mechanics and gives you a variety of tough enemies to dispose of.


I think this game is a victim of awkward pacing and unrealistic fan expectations.

The pacing is much better and the story flows much more naturally when you play the first couple chapters of Chris and Jake's campaigns before starting Leon's. IMO the game should have just been one long campaign to better control the pacing of it.

As for unrealistic fan expectations, I honestly think a big chunk of the people complaining either never played RE2/RE3/RE:CV, or they just love those games too much and have trouble seeing that those games were criticized for the same things back in the day. A lot of the complaints about RE6 can be made about the classic Resident Evil games.

- Campy/Ridiculous/over-the-top story
- Bad voice acting
- Not very scary, cheap jump-scares
- Non-conventional controller layout
- Too action-oriented (read some complaints about RE2/RE3/RE4)

There are plenty other complaints that are totally valid. Too many QTEs, too linear, not enough puzzles (early on in the game), almost no exploring of environments, so on. It's far from a perfect game, but I do think it's a very fun game, and I havn't even touched Mercenaries yet.

If you decide to get this game, a few tips:
- Increase the FOV for god's sake! Standard FOV is unplayable IMO. 15/10/10 is perfect.
- Play the game in the suggested campaign order found in various forums
- Play on a difficulty higher than normal to actually give yourself a challenge, make you fear enemies and make ammo more coveted
- Have fun with the campiness of it all! Stop taking RE so seriously!

reviewText:
A horror/zombie action game with all the wants and needs of a good experience. Characters and story arcs that entice you to love and hate characters. Blooming unlikely love story. Unexpected partnership based on mutual trust. Unresolved and mysterious love interest. PTSD hero, who loses more than he wanted, and gains much more only to lose some. Deceit and disillusionment. And twisted unrequited EVIL love.

It is action, zombies, guns and knives, grenades and gritty puzzles. Not only do you use your skill, but also your brain, something most zombie games don't have. What is truly terrifying is the fact that the 'zombies' are not mindless killing machines (for the most part) but are capable of organisation.

Downside is the ANNOYING camera angles, that though you could get used to after a while, certain campaigns force camera angles that keep changing and warping into almost unworkable conditions that result in your death. QTEs are a pain sometimes but are exciting - thought it depends on you. An overusage of it - in my opinion - but there is an option to turn them off, so that's good. (I'm looking at you Chris/Piers)

Bottom line a product worth its blood and gore. There's a million ways to die and so satisfying when finished - not only cos of the action element, but also the story element. Graphics ain't half bad either, and is plenty reliable as compared to other franchises that are trying to up their game. This Resident Evil has done it in the most balanced way.

What I actually got was one of the most refreshingly playable Japanese-style shooters since Vanquish and Binary Domain. Let's put all the hub-bub aside, as a game with no strings attached; this game has great, tight mechanics and gives you a variety of tough enemies to dispose of.


I think this game is a victim of awkward pacing and unrealistic fan expectations.

The pacing is much better and the story flows much more naturally when you play the first couple chapters of Chris and Jake's campaigns before starting Leon's. IMO the game should have just been one long campaign to better control the pacing of it.

As for unrealistic fan expectations, I honestly think a big chunk of the people complaining either never played RE2/RE3/RE:CV, or they just love those games too much and have trouble seeing that those games were criticized for the same things back in the day. A lot of the complaints about RE6 can be made about the classic Resident Evil games.

- Campy/Ridiculous/over-the-top story
- Bad voice acting
- Not very scary, cheap jump-scares
- Non-conventional controller layout
- Too action-oriented (read some complaints about RE2/RE3/RE4)

There are plenty other complaints that are totally valid. Too many QTEs, too linear, not enough puzzles (early on in the game), almost no exploring of environments, so on. It's far from a perfect game, but I do think it's a very fun game, and I havn't even touched Mercenaries yet.

If you decide to get this game, a few tips:
- Increase the FOV for god's sake! Standard FOV is unplayable IMO. 15/10/10 is perfect.
- Play the game in the suggested campaign order found in various forums
- Play on a difficulty higher than normal to actually give yourself a challenge, make you fear enemies and make ammo more coveted
- Have fun with the campiness of it all! Stop taking RE so seriously!

reviewText:
The good stuff:

--- The game offers not one but four campaigns! This is pretty cool considering the 4 couples you have which means 8 characters - each with a different personality, extra attack or weapon and importance when it comes to the storyline. Also, enemies approaching you differ in each campaign. The same goes to the locales. While Leon and Helena traverse through the big city, a cemetery and a cathedral offing dozens of zombies Chris and Piers do the same but in China. They are attacked by J'avos - these are infected people with the ability to plan their attacks and can also use firearms.

--- Graphics / cutscenes / sound effects -> production value. Well, after episode 5 it was obvious the creators would take this to another level. The game looks stunning and the atmosphere is there. The coop and action sequences once again decrease the horror elements but nobody can say they did not try! Also, there are dozens of cutscenes and in the game's menu you can rewatch all. Altogether I'm sure it will take at least 2 hours to go these in one sitting.

--- Longevity. Once again we have collectibles that come in the form of emblems. I have found many but could not find a lot either. There are no more treasures as collectibles. Instead, there is something else that is dropped by the enemies and they represents points. This amount can be used to purchase skills. These can then be levelled up. 3 skills can be active at a time and there are enemy-specific ones, too. So, you and your coop partner need to work together and decide who equips what. Multiplayer also returns in the form of Mercenaries and there is now a new game mode called Agent Hunt.

The bad stuff:

--- 4 campaigns: In terms of story and characters this is really good but there are too many intersections. In fact, there are boss battles you need to play twice. Really? Of all this it is Ada's (4th) campaign that is the worst. First of all, almost all the areas are familiar and you encounter hardly any new enemies. Throughout all the campaign you know what's going to happen and the ending is a total letdown. Not only this but Ada plays alone. Your friend assumes the role of a so-called Agent - a guy who's just there so that the creators can tell they did really make a coop game. Agent wears a mask and does not have a real name. In the cutscenes you see Ada alone and throughout the campaign Agent cannot interact with anything. You cannot open doors or chests, you cannot solve any puzzles and no QTEs for you (which is actually good). You can pick up bullets, of course and fight with Ada but feel like an unnecessary character who does not even have a story.

--- Cheesiness: If you thought episodes 5's dialogue was bad you are in for a great surprise. Some of the conversations the protagonists have are just dumb. In fact, you can easily guess what will happen next. The script should have been reworked at least 3 times to eliminate some of the worst dialogues this franchise has ever seen.

--- Boss battles: They are waaaaaaaay toooooooooo loooooooooooooong! You battle the same guy while he assumes at least 3 different forms one after the other. The tactic is different as well as the environment. It is not necessarily a problem but the game is very difficult and also you are 100% sure you eliminated your foe when he returns once more to annoy you. I have to admit the enemies are great (each one of them poses a real threat) but you battle them for too long. This gets boring and aggravating considering the difficulty of the game.

--- Difficulty level: This game is annoyingly difficult. From time to time you get a QTE which is next to impossible to complete for the first time. Missing it will result in a death cutscene - well, I appreciate the developers wanted to show me what cutscenes they had conjured up in their mind but this is still pretty annoying. Boss battles can be a pain and the controls do not help either. It is a sad thing to say since this game enables you to do pretty much everything: you can run, do fistfight, dodge and even slide. And finally: you can walk while aiming at an enemy! The problem is with the turning and the speed. Also, the camera does not help and sometimes you get attacked because our heroes are looking at what's going on elsewhere in the distance.

reviewText:
To avoid confusion RE6 is a dynamic 3rd person action game with post-apocalyptic content. It is NOT scary or filled with building up tension. Instead of that game is mainly focussed on QTE ( Quick time events ) and interesting ( Yet Hollywood like ) story that is divided into FOUR relating to each other campaigns ( At least 16+ hours of gameplay ).

Within the story mode if you choose to you CAN co-op with other players or allow them to become one of the ‘biohazards’ in your game. Unlike classic franchise releases game does not posses option to save on the go. Combat system, controls and camera behaviour within the game are fairly easy to get used to. Yet it is a matter of personal taste and devotion to the title.

Multiplayer and all of the DLC content is NOT highly populated hence this game is mainly limited to three modes
(CAMPAIGN, AGENT HUNT & MERCENARIES) For people that like to compete residentevil.net is hosting live events quite often.

reviewText:
Would I recommend RE6  to someone? That's a half-hearted yes. I wish Steam used stars instead of a simple thumbs up or down. If you're a fan of the series and you like the characters that have grown on you over the last decade or so, then yes, RE6 is a good play.

On the other hand, if you're really just casually into the series from a distance or haven't really been following all the games to this point, I'd say, just go ahead and watch the full videos on YouTube to get the gist and skip this purchase.

The Good:  A lot of people really hated on this game in strong ways, and the criticism has some validation. But let's start with the good.

Graphics - A nice improvement from previous RE games, though at times the lighting makes it hard to tell as such. There's several different campaings to go through in this game, each one has some pretty nice visuals and character design.

Gameplay - This is both in the good category, and the bad category. The good part of the gameplay is in the improved combat structure. Overall all the control scheme plays a lot more like a normal 3rd person shooter, making it easier to aim and shoot on the fly. Veterans of other games should pick up the controls fairly intuitively, and I'm glad to say that ditching the old tank-style controls from previous fames feels like quite the improvement.

Characters - We've got some old favorites coming back for long time fans, and some new characters in the form of Helena, Piers, and Jake. Helena is paired up with long time vet of the series, Leon Kennedy, and Jake Muller is paired up with Sherry Birkin, now in a starring role. Chris and Piers have an interesting dynamic as Chris has fallen into a rut, so Piers is almost the spitting image of who Chris was back in RE 1. No matter who you play as, the characters flesh out pretty much the same, but it is entertaining to see how some of the characters have either matured or fallen into disgrace, (like Chris).

Story - This is another category that's both good and bad. The good part of the story is that there's actually 4 whole campaigns to work through, almost like 4 entire resident evil games. Each one takes on an archetype: Leon's is dark and tense, Chris' is very action themed, Jake's is mostly a chase sequence, and Ada's has a lot of the classic puzzle solving and intrigue.

The Bad
Gameplay - Man, despite all the new 3rd person changes, there are some very head banging moments due to unnecessary Quick Time Events (QTE) and bad camera angles. I died more times to stupid button pushes and a poorly rotated camera than I did to any creature in the game. Jake and Sherry's chapter was the worst offender.

Story -  Oh man, where do I begin? It's fun to have 4 different interweaving tales, but the downside is that you really get to a point that you just want the game to GET TO THE POINT. You have to do several boss fights several times on several characters, which can feel very repetitive. But my main issue with the story is that I didn't feel that any of the characters really found any major progression, with the exception of newcomer duo Jake and Sherry. At the end of the game, Leon is still Leon, Ada is still a mystery woman, and Chris is reset back to where he was at the end of RE5. Nothing new gained. Jake/Sherry, Piers, and Helena change, but nothing new with returning cast members.

Characters - The villains in this game needed a lot of work. A LOT. The enemy types are fantastic: tons of work went into making the J'avo and zombies in this game different and creepy from other games. The bosses and lead villains however, have very little in the way of explanations for why they are doing what they are doing it. This is pretty typical for Resident Evil in general, but I really felt the bite of it in this game. You'll find out who the mastermind is of a plot and basically shrug your shoulders and say, but do I care?" Instead of villain development
date: you may just have to fight that same boss 3
hoursPlayed: or 5 times
voteText: which in no way substitutes character development. At some point
helpfulPercent: players want a payoff for their hard work: they want questions answered
votesHelpful:
they want to see what makes the characters tick. Don't expect that here.

The Ugly
Cheapness - Yep
votesTotal: I'm calling shenanigans. I'm a big fan of the Dead Space series
votesFunny: which has a few cheap tricks in the form of jump scares or regenerating bad guys that ♥♥♥♥ you off sometimes. RE6 had this in every campaign. So let me define cheap: despite your ability to annhilate waves of undead and using your nearly omnipotent hand-eye coordination

reviewText: Resident Evil series means a lot to a huge number of different people. For those who played in the first part on the PlayStation, Resident Evil - is patiently waiting until the zombies get into firing range of your shotgun, it's interesting puzzles, this is totally authentic feeling of fear, when a huge biological weapons runs you around the dark and narrow corridor. Very decent representative of the series. Well knotted plot, fully revealed only after a full course for all the characters. Variety of bosses, weapons and locales the same can not but rejoice. Interesting mix of gameplay, there is a grain of good old classic RE and what is from what we've seen, and new developments. Not that funny, it's really a series of steady movement towards action. Horor genre from almost nothing left, and I think not everyone wants to go through all four of the plot in order to learn the essence of the action... Anyway got much better than last RE5.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6
---------------
The Good
+Great Characters
+Large enemy variety
+Lengthy
+Satisfying
+Co-op
+Unlockables
+Replay Value
+Fantastic Movement, very smooth
+Fun bosses to fight
+Immersive
+5 Campaigns
+7 Playable characters
+Campaigns are linked and fill in plotholes

The Bad
-Can be boring at times
-Bland levels
-Some events are really dumb
-Cover system is awkward and useless
-Action scenes are poorly executed
-Quick time events are overused
-No upgrade system
-Infinite inventory
-No merchant
-You will fight a boss more than once
-------
6.9/10
Resident Evil 6 is fun to play with a friend, but playing it alone can be very boring.
Resident Evil 6 is a great action game, but a bad Resident Evil game.

reviewText: I can safely say that this is the worst Resident Evil game ever conceived, but as an entity of its own, it brings fresh ideas and lots of content. Namely, splitscreen. On. The. P. C.\nMerc Mode has never been funner, and Agent Hunt mode is a fantastic twist on L4D's versus mode, which instead drops human-controlled zombies into the single-player campaign, making it feel all the more disconnected and intense (also no vote kicking for giving pills to your buddies or being knocked down even once) due to the lack of communication with the other team (in addition to no racist remarks every time you kill or get killed).\nCross-over co-op between campaigns is also a brilliant idea when it works, I just wish it was more natural somehow. I wouldn't recommend getting RE6 for full price, but if it's on sale, consider giving it a shot.

In conclusion, If you're looking for a fun co-op game to play with a friend, this is for you. If you're looking for survival horror... reviewText: It's just not good.  The combat is crappy, which especially sucks since virtually every single area is chock full of infinitely spawning enemies.  Identical enemy models have wildly fluctuating HP levels, the quicktime events are inconsistent and require either superhuman reflexes, or superhuman button-mashing. reviewText: A very badly done version of Resident Evil. While the storyline might be good, voice acting ok and idea that you can play multiple storylines to understand the game to its fullest extent, the controls are some of the worst I have ever had in a game. Pressing forward in the game does not always push the character in the direction the camera is pointing. This is especially true for parts where there is no fighting, instead you are running from something (plane crash in the beginning, running from helo in the Redfield campaign etc...) After a few rage quits due to poor controls, this game is going to the back burner.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Quick Time events, long un skippable cutscenes and lots of them, truely alien key mapping, and button mashing to solve problems.  It's a collection of all the things we supposedly learned NOT to do when making video games over 15 years ago.  How do these flaws make it past QC?  Quick time events!  So it's supposed to be like a movie.  Ok.  You know what I can do in a movie?  Not watch the same scene over and over again.  I can just skip it.  And press Z to move forward?  WTF?!  Press S to move backward?!  As soon as I saw that I knew this was going to be a terrible game.

reviewText:
An honest review from a long-term Resident Evil fan, all the way from that first zombie encounter back in RE1 on the trusty old Playstation.

RE6 has made no effort to instill any horror elements, nor has it diverged away from it's 'action' seperation brought on by RE4 & RE5. Old and new characters are thrown into the mix, which pleases some and frustrates others. For example, some people are die-hard Chris/Leon fans yet others are getting a bit tired of the franchise having so much focus on them.

Regardless - Despite it obviously cashing in on the success of RE4's action roots, RE6 is still a solid shooter - Just not a solid Resident Evil. The gameplay is fun and RE6 sports an absolutely gargantuan bestiary to fight head on, whether solo or with a partner in Co-Op.

The story is completely brainless and gone are the cheesy lines and hammy acting - Instead, it's basically a case of just blitzing through a mediocre story with whatever character combo you like across their (total of 4) campaigns, all trying to blend together to tell the overall non-existant story.

Sounds pretty negative so far - Yet here I am, clocking up countless hours thanks to the immensely fun Mercenaries - No Mercy mode, having been a Mercenaries fan since RE3 and a sub-game fan since RE2. Having grabbed the game for 15 euro, it's hard to say it wasn't worth it - Afterall, I've been playing that sub-content more than I have some other higher priced 'main' titles - Allowing me the enjoy RE6's strength as a 'shooter' and enjoy the tension of trying to score 300 kill combos while being hunted down by a city full of impressive beasties.

I thoroughly recommend action/shooter fans to give RE6 a legitimate chance, yet die-hard Resi fans of the 'older' generation of RE (and aren't too interested in the shooter-style of RE4/RE5) would likely be better off avoiding it and waiting for the upcoming RE7, which Capcom promises will 'get back to the basics / roots'.

In short:
-Too far away from older Resi's, alienating older fans.
-Entirely shooter orientated with no scares and little tensions.
-Quite QTE reliant during story-mode.

+Good to boot up for the sake of 'fisting a zombie in the mouth' with your favourite Resi Character.
+Agent Hunt & Mercenaries is a lot of fun if you have good company to play with.
+Good to look at, decent acting, good sound and one or two memorable music tracks.

Just an all-round 'OK' game that would have done SO much better if it was not put under the Resident Evil name.

reviewText: Pretty good game overall, although I enjoy it for different reasons than other RE games. Its definitely departed far from its survival horror roots, its much more of a 3rd person action game at this point with a robust combat system that is much more melee and dodge involved. There is a large selection of weapons that you just pick up as you go and ammo is never an issue it seems like, I actually ran into instances where I had to throw some away to make room in my inventory. Its an enjoyable action game though, as long as you have someone to play it with, I would not recommend doing most of the game yourself (although the partner AI is much better than it was in 5). There are several campaigns to go through and extra modes, like mercenaries, so you actually get quite a bit of content in this one. Theres also a bonus mercenaries mode for this pc release where you can play as Left 4 Dead 2 characters and special infected from that game show up, its a neat little addition that changes things up. I'll give it a solid recommendation, just don't expect it to be a survival horror game.

reviewText:
Biohazard 6 is a difficult game to class. On the one hand, it does so many things right, and on the other, some things horribly wrong.

The story is split into 4 campaigns, each with their own gameplay and style; Leon S. Kennedy and Helena Harper team up to take on a traditional zombie outbreak, Chris Redfield and Piers Nevans have an all-out war on terror, Jake Muller and Sherry Burkin battle near-invincible bosses, and Ada Wong solves both gameplay and plot puzzles. Leon and Helena's campaign is the best, with a great atmosphere and fun gameplay involving traditional zombies, with Ada's campaign 2nd for it's plot and puzzle elements. Jake and Sherry have the most unique gameplay, due to Jake's Melee ability complimenting Sherry's ranged ability, with QTEs holding it back from being the better. Chris and Piers share the worst of the four, with their campaign being about as cliche and boring as your average military bromance story. They do crossover, both in terms of style, gameplay and story, and they do all contribute to an overarching story, which is convoluted but interesting enough that it held my attention from beginning to end.

Gameplay is were the game really shines and shows it's unique identity. Movement and combat is a smooth, fast and fluid ride for the most part, broken up by the bane of my existence: Quick Time Events. With gameplay as good as it is, I'm simply lost to find any reason why they thought filling their game with these boring, tiresome interactive cinematics. The excellent combat mechanics, which include dodges, rolls, cover and some character specific moves, are more than enough to carry the game. The other stuff on offer, however, is not. Some driving sequences from Chris and Jake's campaigns are more painful than fun, Ada's helicoper level is mostly boring point and click, and some other odd choices make some sections of the campaign more trouble than it's worth. Multiplayer also handles an odd mix; while the basic combat mechanics are great in modes such as Mercenaries, Mercenaries No Hope, Versus and the other modes that handle normal characters play well, others, such as Agent Hunt, which puts you in the role of a zombie in the campaign, controls awful and feels sluggish. Also, don't bother with the gamepad. It works, but barely, and the keyboard has hotkeys which will make your gameplay experience so much better.

The music and audio is all around high quality, with excellent voice acting, great music and fantastic audio cues enhance the gameplay and the story to awesome hieghts. It played exceptionally well on my 5.1 Surround Sound system and was a thrill to blast the sound to it's maximum levels.

Graphics are all around great. The HUD is small and keeps out of the way for the most part, but the itmes menu could have been handled better. The textures are decent aside from some low-res environmental textures, and the lighting is beautiful. Animations, Capcoms strongest point, I think, is fantastic, though some feel like they're too exagerated and overlong. The art design holds up well and is overall a great-looking game.

Story - 7/10
Gameplay - 6/10
Audio - 9/10
Graphics - 8/10
Controls - 8/10

Total - 38/50

The game ran in max graphics, minus the Anti-Aliasing, at 60fps, with the following specs:

Windows 7 64bit
Intel i5 750 2.6GHz
Nvidia 250GT 1GB
4 GB RAM
1920x1200 Monitor

reviewText:
There are 4 campaigns in the game, each played with different pairs of characters. All the campigns are intertwined with each other, showing each pair's journey through the main storyline. There is a LOT of gameplay here if you want to experience it all. Each campaign seems to play differently as well. It's a pretty great setup. Leon's campaign reminded me of Resident Evil 2, while Jake's campaign reminded me of Resident Evil 5.

This game feels janky and unpolished a lot of the time. The dialogue is lacking and unimpressive. The graphics are mediocre, primarily from low texture quality and repetitive use of objects, textures and the like. Elements in many levels just feel all the same, with just the geometry changing. Some areas look visually impressive, but it's rare and short-lived. The controls and camera are ridiculous at times, but that's always how the Resident Evil franchise has been. Luckily, there are a lot of custom deaths when you fail quick time events, and they never get old.

The level of quality varies GREATLY throughout the game... the beginning of Leon's campaign is just awful, stereotypical, and poorly executed. It gets better later on, though. Jake's campaign felt more consistent and solid, while also being less over-the-top.

Despite all the bad, the game is actually fun COOPERATIVELY. I wouldn't recommend playing this game if you're by yourself, since relying on the AI is not fun, and you can share the ridiculousness of the game with a friend. It's like watching a bad movie and making fun of it... it ends up being fun. I highly prefer Resident Evil 5, as it's better in every single way, but if you're looking for another Resident Evil game, there's a lot of content here.
