reviewText:
I've been a fan o RE since the beginning and unfortunately I can't recommend this game. This would've been fun if it weren't for all the incessant quick time events and chase sequences. The problem is probably with the port, the game is clearly made to be played with a controller. Trying to run with a keyboard during a chase will drive you insane, especially with all the ridiculous fixed camera changes. Seriously, I'm still trying to finish Chris's campaign, that last chase is absurd! And without checkpoints!

Quick time events were the main cause of my deaths. Which is a shame, because when you're going around killing zombies or whatever it get's pretty fun. But before you know it, you're thrust into one those obligatory race, underwater(really?), chase sequences, quick button smashing that all games seem to have nowadays and then everything goes to hell.

The combat gameplay is good, it feels great to be able to take down a zombie with your hands. Every character feels different, the dodging mechanic works (once you get the hang of it) and the weapons, while not the best, definitely doesn't detract from the game.

The story is... fine. Your usual bag of cliches. Although it succeeds in creating a frenetic apocalyptic atmosphere.The characters are great for the most part (though I wish there was a bit more of race and gender diversity). It was nice seeing Leon and Sherry again. But can someone explain to me why the hell does Leon have feelings for Ada? They were together for like, 2 hours, in RE2! Ugh! All his scenes where they mentioned this were groan worthy.

The atmosphere is really where the game succeeds  Especially in Chris and Jake's campaign, the set pieces looked great, from Europe to China, they all had a distinctive feel. Unfortunately, the first half of Leon's was really out of pace. They tried to bring the survival horror aspect back, but it doesn't work anymore, not with the frantic combat style of the game.

Overall I'm disappointed. This game could have been great, but it fails in its execution.

reviewText:
Resident evil...6!... Beautiful, wonderful yet sometimes a little scary :) Resident evil is back with more story line & content. RE6 compared to other RE games, even the classic's, gives more story line selection and characters & more control over your game & how you play it. Fun, exciting & sometimes terrifying.

RE6 add's 2 story mode's with 4 characters. Gamemodes such as onslaught and merc's. Online ranking & full controller support both xlive & direct input's. Split screen mode allowing you to play with a friend or family. Options & settings are great, story mode is fun & multiplayer is even more fun. Steam also seems to give L4D characters in the merc's gamemode switching the zombies and specials into L4D zombies and specials. Overall, game is well made & worth getting on steam.

Overall rating: 9.5
Graphics: 10
Sound: 8
Gameplay: 8.5
Fun factor: 8.5

reviewText: A lot of people here are saying that Resident Evil doesn't work as a horror game anymore, but rather it's become an action title. However, there's very little action. The game's pacing is absolutely funereal. You'll shuffle through boring exploration sections, unskippable cutscenes, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ QTE and awkward action. In nearly 1 and a half hours, I barely shot anything. Does Capcom not know how little people care for the stories and characters in its games? They just keep plodding through. I jumped in expecting some fun zombie shooting action - noooo, I had to slog my way through a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level looking for a character, then looking for a door, then looking for a keycard, then looking for a reason to keep playing this piece of ♥♥♥♥ game.\n\nAs for shooting, the controls are awkward as hell. The game's idea of 'survival horror' is stiffing you on ammo. The interface is cluttered and hard to maneuver, they waste time with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ exposition instead of a proper tutorial to walk you through the controls, and did I mention how slow it was? If you're looking for a fun third-person-shooter on PC, go for Binary Domain and avoid this turd.

reviewText:
After the terribleness of Resident Evil 5, I have to say that Resident Evil 6 has one of the most interesting storylines of any game I've played really, and the way it's incorporated into the gameplay itself, rather than just in a cutscene for example, really shows the direction I hope all games will take.

There's a few spoilers in here, but just to touch on just the main concept of the story, I really think that telling a story about how the protagonist becomes a zombie, and how you get to experience the sort of degredation of their eyesight; like they're kind of blind, and can only sort of sense moving bodies around them, is a really exciting story!! Grappling with the overwhelming sense of the infection; still having to fight off zombies, operate various mechanisms, and try to protect your partner while the world goes black around you, and you can only briefly see glimmers of footfalls. A burst of light as a barrel is knocked over nearby!! Seeing a zombie decapitaded by a trap, and then have to blindly make your way past that trap, just hoping you're somehow clear of it and never being sure at all! It was really exciting, and one of the best gameplay experiences that I can honestly remember having!




. . . .hmm? Oh, ahm, was that all, just a glitch in the game? Because it was happening a lot, and I thought it was, uhmm, maybe intentionally? Oh, er, the game's just really glitchy? Oh. Yeah, it did freeze up a few times too, and, I guess I was pretending that I had fully become a zombie at that point. . .well, if anyone wants to make a game where the player experiences what a zombie sense, and provides the zombie player with a gameplay experience of how a zombie actually behaves, then this is really the game that shows what's that like!! I don't care if it glitches, I really had a lot of fun with it!


It is really, really glitchy, though.

reviewText:
OK, let's see. Why did I say No to this game? Because I don't want Capcom to make the same mistake again.

The game contains 4 campaign, one of which is captivating. I played Leon’s campaign repetitively, like an actual insane person. I can’t say that it has any major issues, expect the game’s general issues, which the entire game has. I know the dialogue is a little more than cheesy, and you won’t really want to listen to the character’s talk, but the rest is fine. The game (I’m speaking exclusively No Hope difficulty, the hardest mode of the game) doesn’t give you much ammo, which makes it much MUCH more survivor than Resident Evil 5, and you’ll have to do a lot of headshots combined with the following melee attack in order to get through chapters. Of course, sometimes it get pretty annoying when killing an enemy is mandatory, you’ve used your bullets judiciously, but the game is refusing to give you bullets and instead keeps showering you with skill points.
This campaign is dark and nostalgic. I actually lived through it. I missed Raccoon city so much; I missed the atmosphere of Resident Evil 3, and this game came so close, which I’m grateful for. Thank you, Capcom.
The bosses, as always, are needy pathetic characters you can’t grow a liking or respect for (which doesn’t count for a flaw.)
Chris’s campaign is where the bugs and issues come to life for the first time, but the campaign still feels like an actual game. Here, you will see enemies actually shooting “through” each other. While you can’t possibly shoot an enemy through another enemy (the first enemy is blocking the other one), enemies can do this. Their bullets fly right through each other and reach you.
It has ridiculous artificial intelligence. When you’re hiding behind a wall and an enemy is using a machine gun from 100 feet away to kill you, the enemy will aim at you even when you’re moving behind the wall. HOW CAN THE ENEMY SEE WHERE I’M MOVING FROM BEHIND THE WALL?
There are these round and explosive enemies who will explode when you get close to them or kick them. Piers, your partner for this session, keeps kicking them all the while, regardless of where you’re standing. If I had a cent for every time Piers killed me, I’d have a dollar.
Then there are the headshots, which is a very crucial thing in the No Hope difficulty of the game. When you do a headshot, then enemy starts crying and pressing the wound, giving you a chance to perform a lethal melee attack. But the thing is, if you do 1000 more headshots, the enemy won’t show reaction again until he’s done crying, meaning you won’t be able to get the enemy to react again until it’s done with his first reaction. Now that’s just a big flaw.
Oh, the Camera, the Camera. Do I even want to tell you about the camera? The heroes are constantly looking around, and the camera follows their looks. When they’re done sightseeing, you’re usually attacked instantly, which is hideously annoying in No Hope difficulty, where you can actually die because of that. Sometimes a bus is following you, and you have to dash in order to escape. The character is looking at his front, but the camera only shows his back, which results in you being blocked by some crate or something, and then dying. In Chris’s campaign, luckily, there isn’t much to block your way. But in Leon’s campaign, you can be sure to die at least once.
There are these cut scenes that you can’t skip, which will annoy you to death for two reasons. One, the enemy has the ability to move during these scene, but you’re not. And when the cut scene is finished, the enemy will attack you instantaneously, giving you null chance of defending yourself.

Now, please pay attention that I got an S (the highest score possible) on every chapter of this game without cheating or using tactics that count as cheating. So I’m not annoyed because I don’t know how to play or anything. The game is seriously flawed.

One time, a truck ran over my partner Helena in chapter one, and she died. I’m only made responsible for my own character in this game. Why the hell does my partner die like that at times?

I don’t have much more to say about Chris’s campaign. I should add that it’s STILL worth playing. Once you get used to the bugs and flaws, you’ll really like this game. It has beautiful bosses. If you know what I mean by beautiful. Really fun to kill.

Don’t even play the third and fourth campaign. I continuously felt like I’m waiting for the game to begin. The chapters were either too short or too long. And they didn’t feel like games, they felt like prologues.

Speaking of prologues, the prologue of the game is most boring thing ever. Helena is dying and you have to save her. The more boring thing is that you have to play that part of the game for a second and third time (as Leon, and then as Ada).

The story was beautiful. This is the only Resident Evil game with an actual storyline, with character development. It’s no longer about saving a certain somebody and escaping a certain town (which happened for five games), this one actually contain some drama. You may even cry. :D Don’t say I didn’t tell ya’. ;)

Verdict:
Do not buy this game if you’re not a Resident Evil fanatic, because you’d only be supporting a failure. You’d be rooting for another game of this type.
There is much more I can say to dissuade you from buying this game, but I’m not gonna. This is becoming longer than I had expected.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 is a game that is constantly throwing new mechanics at the screen to keep things fresh, not actually caring if they are well implemented or even improve the game experience - Yes, you can drive a motorbike, pilot a plane, steer a boat. You can also join another player's game as a creature and try to kill him. Is it fun? Who cares, it's there!
The basic shooting mechanics are solid, but the atrocious amount of frustrating QTEs, poor level design, as well as a laughable bad story/dialog make this game hard to recommend even to die-hard fans of the RE franchise.
However, if you are still interested in the game, make sure to have someone to play with you throughout the campaingn, as a coop buddy is certanly better than the stupid AI.

5,8 / 10

reviewText:
I have no idea what to say about RESIDENT EVIL 6, really. Suppose I'll just ramble a bit.

tl;dr at the bottom

The gameplay is fairly solid and the action is exhilarating, for sure. The production values and graphics are impressive, and playing with a buddy in coop is a blast.
However, what really brings this game down for me is the ludicrous story, illogical character actions, and punishing length of the game.

Those sound like strange criticisms for a Resident Evil game, I know, but they truly transform this game into something that's not Resident Evil. The story is divided into four sections, with 3 of them following different sets of characters, and a final epilogue where everything is wrapped up neatly (that's not including the bonus add-on story mission). Though the action is always rising in pitch, it never truly felt like the story was moving along at the same pace; plot progression would be dragged back by long boss encounters and extensive action scenes where nothing is accomplished, aside from the characters receiving a couple extra scars...which is insane, since many of those sequences should have resulted in grisly death, not near-misses.

Again, seems like a strange criticism for a Resident Evil game, a series known for crazy nonsensical plot elements. But much like the film adaptations, RESIDENT EVIL 6 is an adrenaline-pounded sequel to a series that benefitted most on subtlety and horror, with only tiny slivers of its former glory tacked on.

The game is also brutally long. You'd think that more game equals better, right?
That's not the case here, unfortunately. The game is padded by extensive fight scenes, and progressing through the story feels like a drawn out chore rather than an enjoyable gauntlet. Just when you think you've reached the climax of the game, and must be close to the end, you end up playing for 3 more hours. THEN you're close to the end.
In the final chapters I just wanted the game to be over. I was tired of fighting the same boss, who would always resurrect" himself with some new appendage or mutation. Having bosses continually come back certainly sucks the tension out of the game
date: when you expect that the abomination you just torched will arrive again in 10 minutes.\n\nRESIDENT EVIL 6 is also punishing to completionists: if you want to finish the game "100%" you'll have to go through the entire game TWICE
hoursPlayed: then again as their partner. The play time I currently have logged is from going through the entire game (and the bonus mission) just once. I don't think I have the patience to go through the game a second time.\n\nAlso never expected to find continuity errors in a video game. Before the main game starts you have to play through a tutorial prologue that shows certain characters in peril. However

helpfulPercent: and changes certain events throughout the game as you switch between sets of characters. It's crazy.\n\nThough it has its moments

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1L3U7NwhL4

Resident Evil didn't invent the survival horror genre as we know it, that distinction belongs to 1992's Alone in the Dark, but it is the franchise that popularized the genre and as a result has become the standard bearer. Over the series 20 year history, it has evolved and changed to stay keep up with modern gameplay and mechanics; pre-rendered back drops were ditched in favor of fully 3d modeled environments. Grid based tank controls and fixed camera angles evolved into a tight over the shoulder perspective with swifter character movement and a dedicated single player experience has been replaced by co-operative gameplay. While no one can accuse the franchise of failing to evolve, it's entirely fair to criticize what it has evolved into. Starting with RE4, the series morphed into a more action game, alienating purists but ultimately appealing to a larger audience. Resident Evil 6 is Capcom's attempt to give both purists and newcomers an agreeable middle ground by splitting the game into four smaller campaings with different protagonists and gameplay styles. The problem is that Capcom's attempt to please everyone has given us a game that fully pleases no one.

Players take control of Leon Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Jake Muller and Ada Wong in four separate but interwoven campaigns in an effort to combat the C-Virus. It's a globe spanning whodunit, though players will have cracked the game's mysteries long before the reveal. Players will benefit from having played the other titles in the series in order to have an understanding of the backgrounds of each character. The problem with Resident Evil 6's narrative is that it attempts to be a bigger, more bombastic version of the events in previous games but it only manages to feel needlessly convoluted and dry... The narratives of previous Resident Evil titles have had a silly B movie charm while lovingly fleshing out the game's mythos with countless files and documents. The increase in scope and size ruins the B movie charm but is still too absurd to have blockbuster appeal. The characters have been written into corners and their individual narratives are so complex and independent of each other that this attempt to write these series favorites into the same chain of events is forced and clumsy. It's clear that a narrative reboot is in order for the franchise to retain the charm and quality the first games were known for.

Gameplay has received and overhaul that moves Resident Evil further toward pure action. Characters can now aim while moving and heal with the press of a button. While these tweaks are convenient, they take away much of the tension present in previous entries to the franchise. A clunky Gears of War style cover system has also been added pushing the gameplay too far from the series' roots. Puzzles are restricted to Leon and Ada's campaign further betraying the roots of the series. In addition to these changes the game features idiotic cinematic action sequences on motorcycles, jets and snowmobiles that offer needless spectacle. The attempt to force these visually complex and flashy moments into the game cheapens the whole experience. Between the gunplay and watching your characters survive plane crashes, car crashes, helicopter crashes and surviving falls from high places a few zombies don't really pose a credible threat. With its ultra resilient characters Resident Evil 6 could be reskinned as a Justice League game with little effort. As with other action games expect an irritating amount of stick waggling and button mashing thanks to copious quick time events. A spare controller might be required. The melee system has been overhauled as well offering a number of context sensitive commands that frankly make it completely overpowered. Seriously, you can punch your way through half of the game on professional difficulty. It has never been easier to conserve ammo in a Resident Evil though it's not like the game isn't generous in that regard anyway. Speaking of conserving ammo, you will actually be spending most of your time dumping it on the ground thanks to a miserable inventory system. Your characters carry around more guns than John Matrix during the finale of Commando but it doesn't leave much room for bullets. There is also no item swapping between AI or human partners and the UI itself is atrocious.

Each campaign generally offers a players a different flavor and some try to recall previous games in the franchise. Leon's campaign is our favorite since it is generally the most traditional. There are a few puzzles and the environments in his campaign are among the most atmospheric in the game. Chris' campaign is pretty much an unofficial Gear of War title, emphasizing gunplay and taking players through a fictional war torn eastern European country called Edonia. It's the weakest campaign in the game as a result of it's fixation with bullets and chest high walls. Jake Muller's campaign is interesting at first since he and series darling Sherry Birkin have to face off against a Nemesis-like creature called the Ustanak. Unlike Resident Evil 3 and Resident Evil 2's scenario B featuring Tyrant, the game design telegraphs the appearance of the Ustanak killing any tension or sense of unpredictability this unstoppable beast might have otherwise provided. The Ustanak also facilitates some of the obnoxious  action set pieces that force players into watching ♥♥♥♥♥♥, bloated cinematic sequences while mashing buttons during quick time events. Since Ada takes her campaign on alone it's more about stealth and offers several puzzles. It works well enough and comes out as one of the stronger campaigns. Having several interconnecting campaigns also means that you replay the same segments with multiple characters and it's completely unnecessary and lazy. If you are not playing the same sections with different characters you can expect to experience the same gameplay gimmicks; like finding three keys in a labyrinth of hallways while being chased by unkillable regenerators. It's like waking up in Bill Murray's shoes in Groundhog Day. Only worse.

While it may sound like this is the most awful Resident Evil game to date, the truth is that it was one of the best action games on the market when it was released. When seen as a competitor to games like Gears of War it's stumbles and inconsistencies are more forgivable. The frustrating thing is there are moments in the game that are excellent and are a sign of what could have been if this game was focused on being a Resident Evil game first and pleasing a mass audience second. We expect moody atmosphere, slower paced gameplay and tension from anything in a box that says Resident Evil. In their attempt to give everyone something to like about this game they have created a game that lacks cohesion and focus. After experiencing one of Resident Evil 6's stand out moments, it doesn't take long before the game has your trudging through more cover based shooting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or waggling your stick like you're having a seizure.

It's four campaigns plus Mercenaries mode equates to over 100 hours of entertainment for fans. Each campaign attempts to use some of the best aspects of previous games to give players a total package. Yet, when it all comes together the only thing that makes it feel like a Resident Evil game are the familiar faces of Chris, Ada, Leon and Sherry. In an age where we often get so little for our buck, Capcom tried to give us everything fans could want but it's so inconsistent; wasting time and effort to give players glitz and spectacle instead of tension and scares. It would seem that the survival horror genre that we fell in love with in the 90's is dead. The twitch fodder hide and seek games that are now considered survival horror are mechanically shallow. I hope that the RE2 remake will remind Capcom why the franchise was brilliant.

reviewText:
With Resident Evil 4, a video game series once known for survival horror and tank controls turned into a third person shooter with tank controls. Resident Evil 6 follows this direction even more consequently than previous installments. There's plenty to shoot, ammo is no longer scarce (true for every campaign save for Chris', for some reason), the characters are more agile than ever before and apart from Ada's campaign, every segment can be played cooperatively. Horror is only present in form of the various body horror moments, the monsters and the gore, of course. Little has changed in terms of mechanics and unless you were expecting survival horror to return, RE6 couldn't be better. In theory.

Unfortunately, the game is just littered with bad design decisions. For instance, the dreaded button mashing sequences have returned - with a vengeance. While they have been relatively few in-between before, in RE6 you stumble over them every few steps. Every time you think the game finally lets you play, it snatches control away from you in favor of another chase sequence. And even though the characters are as agile as they can get in a Resident Evil game, the zombies can now leap 4 meters (if you're American, convert it) and every time they get hold of you, you will engage in yet another QTE square dance.

In a series that has been known for zombies, you fight relatively few of those. For the most part, enemies consist of gun-toting humanoid mutants, placing RE6 even closer to a run-of-the-mill third person shooter. In addition to that, the railroading is insane, the setpieces are not as varied or interesting as they could be and the story, while absolutely ridiculous, takes itself way too seriously. If I didn't know better, I'd say RE6 is a parody of current-gen game design.

There are four campaigns in total, which offer different play styles: Leon's campaign is the closest to the more traditional RE games and the only one featuring zombies, Chris' campaign is a full-on third person shooter, Jake's campaign plays like a hybrid of both and Ada's campaign focuses on what Capcom perceives as stealth. RE6 tries to have its cake and eat it, but ends up doing nothing right. As a result, the game feels weirdly unfocused and makes it evident that Capcom doesn't know where to take the series.

Despite its glaring flaws, I can't bring myself to hate the game since the mechanics are rock-solid. The gunplay feels satisfying since zombies react properly to hits: A shot to the chest will throw them back or make them stagger; a shot to the leg will make them fall over, giving you enough time to line up additional shots or go for a melee finisher. Capcom even integrated a gore engine, which is always a nice touch in a game featuring the walking dead. RE6 is at its strongest when it's just pitting you against a horde of zombies and at its weakest when it's going for cinematic action. Unfortunately, moments like the latter are way too present. It almost seems like Capcom doesn't have any confidence in the game holding its own with all those other fancy third person shooters around.

There is a good game sleeping in here, mostly in the shape of the Mercenaries mode, which I enjoyed more than all four campaigns combined. Popping heads and body slamming zombies all day - this is what RE6 could have been: pure genocidal fun. It only takes a lot of digging to get there. If you like action games and have a high tolerance for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, check out RE6, but don't blame me if you want to fire it into the sun. In case you were expecting a return to the old days of survival horror: Don't even bother. Personally, I don't really care what you do with an established series as long as you do it right.

I for one am looking forward to Resident Evil Kart.

Despite all bad reviews I liked this game very much. It takes a short time to get used to controls, but once you do it's great fun. It's true however that the game is more action than survival horror. And online matching system is really bad. A friend and I tried intersection with each other, we both in the same city. However gave up after a few attempts. This also affects mods, you can't play anyone other than mercenaries and sometimes survivor.

Overall,
pros: fantastic visuals, very long story playtime, story intersecitons, great player control
cons: bad online matching system, more action than horror.

reviewText:
Extremely fun with a Co-op partner. Lots of replayability, as each character in each campaign has separate quick time events, and objectives during split up areas.

The storyline is very cool, you gain a bit more insight into it as you progress through each campaign, all of which occur concurrently. Ada's campaign should be done last, as it pulls everything together and provides backstory.

If you're used to RE games, play this on Professional or No Hope. The game is far easier than RE4 and RE5 on similar difficulties (Professional in RE6 is ~ equivalent to Normal in  RE5, and No Hope is equivalent to a fresh Veteran run). Nonetheless, an amazing Coop game, and I hope Capcom keeps making RE games in this vein.

This is a good f**king game... Worth every penny!!

The story is set in 2013 and U.S President Adam Benford has decided to disclose the truth behind the Raccoon City Destruction Incident in 1998. The prime impetus behind choosing to do so is to curtain the revival in bioterrorist activity. Leon S. Kennedy, President’s close friend and Raccoon City survivor is standing by his side through this but as luck would have it; the venue suffers a bioterrorist attack and Leon is confronted with a situation he could’ve never imagined. The President has disfigured beyond recognition and now Leon has to make a decision that will change everything. Simultaneously, Bioterrorism Security Assessment Alliance member Chris Redfield reaches the fictitious city of Lanshiang akin to Hong Kong, which is under a threat of a bioterrorist attack. With all countries exposed to these threats and attacks, the entire world’s population is unified by a common fear and anxiety that there is nothing that can be done.

reviewText:
A hulking beast of a game.

It has more content and waifus than you can shake a stick at. (okay only two really, Helena is a slag)

Not only does it have four fullsize campaigns (seriously, it could have easily been four seperate games), an updated and improved mercs mode, and a totally revamped and impressive control scheme, it also adds some unique gameplay mechanisms, such as jake's melee and even a left 4 dead-esque versus mode.

The narrative, while never being a strong point of the franchise, is still told in an interesting way, with each plot thread touching on the others at various points throughout the game.

It's a very worthy installment in the franchise, giraffe ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or no.

That said, there are two major faults with the game: Despite increased graphical fidelity, it actually manages to look worse than RE5. This is due to the totally amateurish lighting. It is seriously so bad in places, they must have had a single intern doing the lighting for the whole game.

The second fault is: no Wesker.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 might not be the return to survival horror that some people have hoped for, but it's a pretty neat action game.

A number of changes have been made to the combat system that doesn't quite get it's chance to shine in the campaign, but once you take it into Mercenaries mode and learn all the tricks you'll find out how amazing it is.

The campaign is long and diverse with homages to many of the tropes of the older games. It might feel too fragmented for some and it'll undoubtly lead to some less choice moments for others, but I found it to be an overall pleasent experience that was nicely tied together through Ada Wong's campaign, which I suggest you play last.

reviewText: Not as bad as people make it out to be. This game would probably have had less of a **** storm if it was a new IP. True, it's more actiony. True, it's more linear than RE5. And sure, the game's checkpoint system holds your hand leaving you feel like a little lost puppy who needs to be babied. But, honestly, it's not THAT bad. The game still has some redeeming qualities, and there's a few parts where Capcom did a good job. The second chapter of Leon's campaign is a perfect example of a good level done right. Despite it's linearity and confusing controls there's a lot of good stuff crammed in this game. It's not perfect but it at least deserves a solid 7 out of 10 which, in my book, is good.""

reviewText:
Also als Fan von der Reihe muss ich echt sagen das dieses Spiel gut ist, zwar nicht überragend aber man kann es Spielen, Ich finde es gut das man die verschiedenen Charaktere wieder findet (Leon, Ada, Sherry, Chris).

Das spiel hat verschiedene szenarien und man hat mit allen seinen Spass, wobei jeder Charakter unterschiedlich schwer ist.
Auch hat mir gefallen das das Szenario mit Leon in der Art wie Resident Evil 2 und 3 ist, man erfährt auch gleich zu beginn wie es nach RE4 weiter geht.
Jedoch vermisse ich in dieser Reihe den Charakter von Jill oder die erwähnung.
Ich finde es gut das bei diesen Spiel nicht die Rede von diesen Las Plagas Virus die rede ist und keine komischen Dinger aus den Köpfen kommt.

Was etwas eintönig ist, ist der Kampf gegen Simmons (Leon und Helena), dieser zieht sich wie Kaugummi und Simmons gibt es in allen möglichen Varrianten (wer hätte es gedacht er lässt sich schwer töten)..... aber wie um alles in der Welt kann Simmons am Ende bei der Flucht von Leon wieder da sein er wurde doch aufgepiesst und mit gefühlten 1000 schuss durchlöchert....

Bei den anderen Mission und Charakteren ist es auch sowas die Zombies oder besser die J´avo`s tragen sonstwas für waffen mit sich rum und schiessen einfach nur und bei uns herscht zwischenzeitig Munitionsknapphei was das Spielen nicht einfacher macht....

reviewText: A more polished, better looking, better controls, better herb system, better weapons and inventory system, and more fun RE game than 4 and 5 were. That's because those games didn't have zombies and this does and like I said, just everything about the game is done much better than those games combined. The only serious flaw with it is that it is very linear. You can re-run a campaign as the second character to make it a little more interesting. The herb system is the best one yet in a RE game: you find herbs, hit a key to automatically combine them and add them to your inventory as pills, then hit 1 to take a pill. It couldn't be more simple, yet some reviewers complained about it, lol. They also complained about there being so many quick time events. QTE's killed RE5 and ♥♥♥♥♥ it of a lot of fun, they were horrible, especially the QTE Wesker fight. But they are done differently here and are actually fine. However still annoying: QTE's DO NOT belong in ANY games. They do not constitute actual gameplay, they are just a bother.\nThe only enemies in RE4 were incest loving hillbillies and in RE5 99% of enemies were shirtless black guys. reviewText: Resident Evil 5 was a nice surprise for me early in the gen. Playing local co-op with my brothers was something that was insanely fun, though playing any game in co-op can sometimes mask the issues with an average or worse game. While RE5 was not a small game, the direct chapter progression was enjoyable; you could play the game in smaller chunks and never feel committed to exceedingly long play sessions. However, RE6 just feels comparatively massive, with some chapters taking 90 minutes or more to complete on first go though. This result in there being a sort of invisible deterrent to actually starting up the game for me, knowing that I might not see my first results screen for a significant period of time.\n\nThe gameplay is largely improved, with a more modern TPS-like combat system along with some deeper close range abilities and quick fire mechanics that allow for slightly more interesting ways to survive the zombie hoards. The game remains highly cinematic and enjoyable and the voice acting is generally top notch. However, the game itself just seems very soulless. I don’t care for any of the characters, I feel nothing when someone dies (regardless of importance), and having so many branching story arches means that not enough time is really spent getting to know any one person or understanding any one situation. There’s a point in the game where a bio-nuke of sort hits a city and another where a playable character effectively condemns himself and yet there just simply no sense of weight to the situations at all. Another shortcoming is a  prevalent use of instant fail QTEs or QTE like sections where you have to do something such as run a particular direction in a particular manner in a particular amount of time or be instantly offed because the game demands it. I had significantly more deaths of this variety than that of dying by making mistakes in combat or such. The game remains, however, to be a stupidly entertaining blockbuster kind of experience, especially if you are able to play the game in co-op.

reviewText:
I do really love RE series, even though I read a lot of negative review of this game I still love it and already playing this game over and over. Yeah this game is a little more action than horror, but it fixed the crappy movement of old RE series. If you think lack of survival, the try NO HOPE difficulty. I had try Leon story and it is really challenging. The story may be a little bit awkward and doensn't make senses sometime but it is a game so just enjoy it.
There are still few gliches and minor bug like when I played mercenaries using Chris and I sliding while running the my char was sinking into earth which make me had to end the game. But there are a lot of game with worse problem, so as long it didn't happened occasionally I could stand with it.
I played co op mode with my cousin and it really do have double fun since the AI won't make mistakes and have unlimited ammo while my cousin do a lot more joke.
Weaponry is a little bit different than RE4 or RE5. I prefer the previous series weaponry which allow me to freely customize and upgrade my shotgun.
Leon story bring back the memories of Raccoon city, Chris story has a lot more gunfight like a RE5, Jake story a little bit more like RE3 when ustanak chases him and Sherry over and over, and lastly Ada story just like RE4 when you play a solo game.
In the end my suggestion is if you have a friend or family who share the loves of RE series then play this game coop, it worth your time.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 is a fantastic game, if you come into it with the right expectations.

If you expect survival horror in the vein Resident Evil is known for, you'll be sorely disappointed. Ammo is plentiful, there are no jump scares, and the majority of the combat is fast and quick, not slow and threatening. While the plot measures up to Resident Evil 6 standards of being stupidly, hilariously bad and awesome, and the tone is ominous, this game does not stick to the roots in the gameplay. It's action horror, not survival horror.

I cannot and will not hold that against the game though, because the new system is so solid. It's quick, responsive, lets the player easily keep pace with the action going on around them, and has a cover system that feels more fluid than a lot of other 3rd person shooters. The melee combat works well enough, the enemies are varied and always pose a challenge, and all of this works together with one of the more fluid co-op experiences I've ever seen.

Don't expect many people online to just drop in with you, as the PC version isn't the most well-populated Co-op place. That's not a problem though, because the game's partner AI is both invulnerable, and hyper-competent. You'll have no trouble getting through the game. And it's a good port too; better graphics (even better if you want to slap ENB or SweetFX on), and  all the quicktime events indicate the actual keys you bound, not just HIT ATTACK? OH GOD WHAT DID I BIND ATTACK TO".

If you're a fan of Resident Evil and won't mind a fast-paced shooter version of it
date: buy this now. If you see this game on sale for 20 bucks and want to know if it's worth it
recommended: it is. You'll easily get 15-20 hours of good single player out of it
hoursPlayed: plus the multiplayer modes."

reviewText:
Well, yeah, I would say this is worth playing, not the BEST resident evil game but well made holding 4 campaign modes, all with their own areas that overlap with others, a good co-op feel and system as well as a really fun score attack mode.
One of the things I really loved about this though was the sheer number of contextual actions it allows you, be it taking an ax out of a zombies head to plunge it into it's hear or taking a severed hand attacking you and throwing it into a microwave.

Honestly it isn't the resident evil we all grew up with, but that does not stop it being a good game and one I plan to play again, it looks great, sounds great and it shows that some of the people who made it actually cared a lot more then the press hate it got as soon as it came out, get it on sale, give it a go and have fun.

reviewText:
A lengthy game that's split into 4 campaigns; length is around 24 hours in total. There's also some multiplayer modes, but no one plays them. The mercenaries mode is as fun as before, and there are 9 characters to pick from, 16 if you count the alternate costumes. As for the campaigns:

Leon: Touted as the best campaign, it's the lengthiest and the 'main' one, since more of the plotline is revealed. Overall decent, some chapters are better than others. Chapter 1 is linear as ♥♥♥♥ and a missed opportunity, while chapter 4 and 5 is  the game's crowning achievement.

Chris: zombies with guns; turns into a bland third person shooter in chapter 2; gets good again in the following chapter. Overall the weakest campaign because it tries to be a generic third person shooter.

Jake: an interesting campaign. It tries being like RE3, but the creature chasing you disappears a fifth of the way into the game before reappearing randomly at the end. Overall it's a level below Leon's campaign.

Ada: My pick for the best campaign; it's built as a single player experience with a lot more puzzles and sneaking around than the other campaigns. The entire story comes together here, winds up being kinda silly and simplistic.

All in all I'd say around a 6 or 7. It's decent, and if you're into RE it's pretty good.

reviewText:
Melee Masters 6 takes the series to an even more action oriented direction by removing all inventory management and substituting shops and money with perks and xp.

Capcom tries really hard to appeal to as large of an audience as possible with their woman and a giraffe" approach.

Even though Melee Master veterans will love seeing a lewd woman make her return in this title Capcom has added a giraffe in attempt to get the attentions of players who don't buy games that don't have atleast one giraffe in them.

The problem is though MM6 fails to fully cater to anyone. Fans of the woman don't really want the giraffe in their game and the fans of the giraffe don't all really care for the woman.

It's no secret Japanese look to America for inspiration and then put their own unique spin on what they learn. It's quite clear when you look at not only the direction game has taken but how Capcom does business these days.

But the game has local co-op so just for that I'm going to give the game a solid 9/10.

The online doesn't work so that's all you've got really. I mean we all have friends who come over and play games with us regularly right?

So yeah as I said

reviewText:
Wonderful game in my opinion. The biggest plus of this game is the story. There are four connected campaigns with 7 main characters who meet each other at some points of the story. All these campaigns differ due to the different characters.

If you choose to play Leon's story - it's classical Resident Evil: there are puzzles, horror and some shooting. Chris's campaign is more of a shooter because he's a soldier. If you play Jake's campaign - it's action with elements of melee combat and stealth. Ada's campaign is the most difficult because you play solo. It contains puzzles and action sequences.

Graphics are pretty good, especially the main characters. Although, the environment textures are sometimes awful.

All in all it's a good port to PC, though controls sometimes get uncomfortable because of camera angle.

I give this game 9 out of 10. It took me more than 25 hours to beat all 4 campaigns. There are some collectibles, so it's worth to replay it again some time.

reviewText:
Coming from all Resident Evil games since the first one, I would have to say that they did a very good job on Reisdent Evil 6.

Sure, most of the critics have already a foundation of bringing it down since they're already basing it on Resident Evil: Operation Raccoon City (and I agree with ORC being bad) but that's them. That's their opinion.

If there is one significant element in Resident Evil 6, it's the NUMBER. The number 6, something significant, something I haven't FELT since I have played that game back then. Megaman X6 was that game and it WAS HARD. But I enjoyed it, and I have felt the same way I have died so many times here in Resident Evil 6, call it CHEAP DEATH but whoever said dying in a megaman game was also a CHEAP DEATH? Same thing.

Everything was griping in the game, from start to finish. From the way I rushed the hordes of J'avos to the stealth game of Ada's. I had to point out though that Ada's Bowgun was surprisingly weak. That's my only complaint but it's pretty minor and I'll get used to it.

Anyway, I'll stop the spoiler from here. Resident Evil 6 is for people who like their game on a hardcore tension. It's not a walk in the park and it's not going to win the hearts of most gamers today. But it's more of a Fan Service for gamers who like their game tough and a lot of Cheap Deaths on the side.

reviewText:
My first Resident Evil game, and considering I had no idea what I was getting into. I must say I have thoroughly enjoyed  learning more about the characters within this game, and the twists and turns that fate has for them within each of their campaigns. The added co-op really helped someone(me) who's relatively new to survival-horror adapt and enjoy all the campaigns.

The multiplayer modes, the Ustanak Cat-and-Mouse/Hide-and-Seek mode really can get your heart going. Mercenaries mode is also alot of fun. You really get to have fun with all the characters and learn what each of them and their guns can do.

There is so much in the game to do, learning about the characters, the virus, the B.O.W's, hunting down serpent emblems, earning points to unlock perks for weapons, it's an awesome experience and I look forward to playing more Resident Evil games.

reviewText:
Also als Fan von der Reihe muss ich echt sagen das dieses Spiel gut ist, zwar nicht überragend aber man kann es Spielen, Ich finde es gut das man die verschiedenen Charaktere wieder findet (Leon, Ada, Sherry, Chris).

Das spiel hat verschiedene szenarien und man hat mit allen seinen Spass, wobei jeder Charakter unterschiedlich schwer ist.
Auch hat mir gefallen das das Szenario mit Leon in der Art wie Resident Evil 2 und 3 ist, man erfährt auch gleich zu beginn wie es nach RE4 weiter geht.
Jedoch vermisse ich in dieser Reihe den Charakter von Jill oder die erwähnung.
Ich finde es gut das bei diesen Spiel nicht die Rede von diesen Las Plagas Virus die rede ist und keine komischen Dinger aus den Köpfen kommt.

Was etwas eintönig ist, ist der Kampf gegen Simmons (Leon und Helena), dieser zieht sich wie Kaugummi und Simmons gibt es in allen möglichen Varrianten (wer hätte es gedacht er lässt sich schwer töten)..... aber wie um alles in der Welt kann Simmons am Ende bei der Flucht von Leon wieder da sein er wurde doch aufgepiesst und mit gefühlten 1000 schuss durchlöchert....

Bei den anderen Mission und Charakteren ist es auch sowas die Zombies oder besser die J´avo`s tragen sonstwas für waffen mit sich rum und schiessen einfach nur und bei uns herscht zwischenzeitig Munitionsknapphei was das Spielen nicht einfacher macht....

Alles in allen Kann ich dieses Spiel nur empfehlen und ist ein muss für alle Fans der Reihe.
Die Steuerung ist gut und lässt sich leicht handhaben man kann während des Laufens nachladen und schiessen.
Der schulterblick beim schiessen macht es einfacher.....

Also man hat lange Spielspass, sogar in den coop Modus, wo man schauen kann wer die meisten Punkte hat ^^

reviewText: While not the best Resident Evil to date (RE2 still holds that crown) RE6 is still a fun game. I've played all campaigns and while there are some things that do not belong in an RE game such as a ton quick time events and the same level and set peice you'll have to finish twice because they make you play them as part of each characters campaign. Fortunatly the controls are responsive and have a wide variety of weapons and melee attacks for each character. The visuals are also quite impressive given it's a console port. I wouldn't buy this at full price, wait as I did and pick it up for 75% off. It's well worth that price. Also the Mercs mode is supposed to be the best in the series but I've yet to try that out.

reviewText:
With Resident Evil 4, a video game series once known for survival horror and tank controls turned into a third person shooter with tank controls. Resident Evil 6 follows this direction even more consequently than previous installments. There's plenty to shoot, ammo is no longer scarce (true for every campaign save for Chris', for some reason), the characters are more agile than ever before and apart from Ada's campaign, every segment can be played cooperatively. Horror is only present in form of the various body horror moments, the monsters and the gore, of course. Little has changed in terms of mechanics and unless you were expecting survival horror to return, RE6 couldn't be better. In theory.

Unfortunately, the game is just littered with bad design decisions. For instance, the dreaded button mashing sequences have returned - with a vengeance. While they have been relatively few in-between before, in RE6 you stumble over them every few steps. Every time you think the game finally lets you play, it snatches control away from you in favor of another chase sequence. And even though the characters are as agile as they can get in a Resident Evil game, the zombies can now leap 4 meters (if you're American, convert it) and every time they get hold of you, you will engage in yet another QTE square dance.

In a series that has been known for zombies, you fight relatively few of those. For the most part, enemies consist of gun-toting humanoid mutants, placing RE6 even closer to a run-of-the-mill third person shooter. In addition to that, the railroading is insane, the setpieces are not as varied or interesting as they could be and the story, while absolutely ridiculous, takes itself way too seriously. If I didn't know better, I'd say RE6 is a parody of current-gen game design.

There are four campaigns in total, which offer different play styles: Leon's campaign is the closest to the more traditional RE games and the only one featuring zombies, Chris' campaign is a full-on third person shooter, Jake's campaign plays like a hybrid of both and Ada's campaign focuses on what Capcom perceives as stealth. RE6 tries to have its cake and eat it, but ends up doing nothing right. As a result, the game feels weirdly unfocused and makes it evident that Capcom doesn't know where to take the series.

Despite its glaring flaws, I can't bring myself to hate the game since the mechanics are rock-solid. The gunplay feels satisfying since zombies react properly to hits: A shot to the chest will throw them back or make them stagger; a shot to the leg will make them fall over, giving you enough time to line up additional shots or go for a melee finisher. Capcom even integrated a gore engine, which is always a nice touch in a game featuring the walking dead. RE6 is at its strongest when it's just pitting you against a horde of zombies and at its weakest when it's going for cinematic action. Unfortunately, moments like the latter are way too present. It almost seems like Capcom doesn't have any confidence in the game holding its own with all those other fancy third person shooters around.

There is a good game sleeping in here, mostly in the shape of the Mercenaries mode, which I enjoyed more than all four campaigns combined. Popping heads and body slamming zombies all day - this is what RE6 could have been: pure genocidal fun. It only takes a lot of digging to get there. If you like action games and have a high tolerance for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, check out RE6, but don't blame me if you want to fire it into the sun. In case you were expecting a return to the old days of survival horror: Don't even bother. Personally, I don't really care what you do with an established series as long as you do it right.

I for one am looking forward to Resident Evil Kart.

reviewText: A more polished, better looking, better controls, better herb system, better weapons and inventory system, and more fun RE game than 4 and 5 were. That's because those games didn't have zombies and this does and like I said, just everything about the game is done much better than those games combined. The only serious flaw with it is that it is very linear. You can re-run a campaign as the second character to make it a little more interesting. The herb system is the best one yet in a RE game: you find herbs, hit a key to automatically combine them and add them to your inventory as pills, then hit 1 to take a pill. It couldn't be more simple, yet some reviewers complained about it, lol. They also complained about there being so many quick time events. QTE's killed RE5 and ♥♥♥♥♥ it of a lot of fun, they were horrible, especially the QTE Wesker fight. But they are done differently here and are actually fine. However still annoying: QTE's DO NOT belong in ANY games. They do not constitute actual gameplay, they are just a bother.\nThe only enemies in RE4 were incest loving hillbillies and in RE5 99% of enemies were shirtless black guys. Thankfully RE6 brought back ZOMBIES! FINALLY. GOD DUDE? ♥♥♥♥ing Capcom. Amazed this was such a good port because normally they can't port for ♥♥♥♥.\nThe women are super hot and the game is a blast. If it were not for its high linearity, it would be a 9/10 easily. As it stands though, 7/10, buy this for sure.

reviewText:
Nice Co-op TPS Action game. RE 6 keeps you in a game from start to the end. Good multiplayer modes that keeps you in a game after campaign completion for a lot of time. Good campaign and multiplayer replayability.
This game much better than RE 5, but slightly below RE 4(due to lack of puzzles plurality).

I am surprised, of what Game Press waited of this game(maybe some innovations, new gameplay features or something else...) This game was not going to follow the canons of the survivor-horror classic from the start of developing. It's just a good continuation of a Resident Evil Franchise, no more, no less...

This game is clearly deserving of assessment is not less than 8.

But I have two bad parts of this PC port:
1)a LOT OF bugs, and consoles controls(you'll see it well in the Creatures' gameplay), low customizable controls... (I think it's more likely to be fixed with a future patches in the next six months(I hope so))
2)Bad graphics and graphic customization and very low resolution of Textures.(Comparing with Resident Evil 5...)

I think for 6 months, CAPCOM could make a better PC port. But I think that they were mistreat the PC port after hearing low estimates of Game Press...

You played a cruel joke to PC players, CAPCOM...
Do not repeat this mistake with upcoming PC port of Resident Evil: Revelations...

reviewText:
~Nechce se ti číst do detailů? Přečti si Shrnutí!

Resident Evil 6/ Biohazard 6 (originalní název) je third-person akční lineární střílečka, dělaná pro dva hráče.
Začal bych kampaní, za kterou bych přidal dost bodíků. Kampaň je dlouhá a dokonce rozčleněná na 5 etap a ty etapy ještě na kapitoly. Kampaň má dokupy něco kolem 30 hodin, což je víc než dostačující.
Nalezneme zde Intro, což je, jak již název napovídá, pouze jeden level kde nás hra seznámí co a jak.

Kampaně -
Leonovu kampaň. Tato kampaň je takové vaše typické moderní Resident Evil, procházíme různé lokace, střílíme klasické zombie a sem tam potkáme něco silnějšího. U mě je tato kampaň na druhém místě ze čtyř dostupných. (nepočítám intro)

Chrisovo kampaň. Hrajeme za člena BSAA Chrise Redfielda a nebo za jeho parťáka Pierse Nivanse a snažíme se ,jako každý charakter ze hry, polapit Adu Wong a zachránit svět před hromadným Bio útokem. Tahle recenze není spoiler free takže dál k tomu nic.
Avšak kdybych měl kampaň zhodnotit tak Chrisovo je asi nejhorší, stále není špatná, ale ze všech dostupných je nejhorší.

Jakeovo kampaň. Hrajeme zde za Jakea nebo Sherry a tahle kampaň má dle mě tu nejzajímavější zápletku a i levely. Jake je imunní vůči C-Viru a Sherry má zajistit aby se v bezpečí dostal do laborek a oni mohli udělat vakcínu. Avšak Ada si to nenechá líbit a pošle nezničitelného Ustanaka který ma za každou cenu zabít Jakea a donést ho k ní. A bude se snažit fakt tvrdě. Tato kampaň je jednoznačně u mě na prvním místě.

A jako poslední tu máme kampaň Ady Wong. Která se mi zas líbí ve faktu že je dost odlišná od ostatních. Není v ní až tolik akce a v první misi se máte dokonce snažit jí projít stealth, což mě docela překvapilo na moderní Resident Evil. Ačkoliv i přesto jí mám na druhém nejhorším místě, hned za Chrisem.


Gameplay -
Jak bylo zmiňováno na začátku, toto RE si opět zahrajeme z pohledu třetí osoby. Budeme sbírat náboje do 400 typů zbraní, hledat skill pointy a taky marně koukat po Zelených rostlinách které jaksi charakter zpracuje a pak si z nich dobijí život. To taky není žádná novinka. Ačkoliv, byl zlepšen aiming systém. A jde to vidět. Znatelně se zde líp míří než v RE5. Stále to není úplně ťip ťop ale přesto ukázka zlepšení tu je.
Co se týče movementu, máme tu celkem dost tlačítek. Můžeme sprintovat, chodit pomalu, dodgovat dopředu i do stran a bůh ví co ještě. Takže tady je toho nejspíš dost.
Zároveň co mi přišlo dost zajímavé je to, že i přesto že hra používá milion tlačítek na různé akce, tak např. na reload a sbírání věcí je to samé tlačítko! Což mi ale nakonec přišlo docela pohodlné.

Ovládání -
K tomuhle mám několik věcí co říct. Je to šílené, ne tak jako ARMA ale stálé ŠÍLENÉ! Je tu milion akcí na různá tlačítka a do toho i další milion kombinací. Já osobně jsem si např. změnil přehazování itemů na  3+M3 a přeházování zbraní je klasicky M3 (kolečky u myši), takže to byla ukázka.
Zároveň tu je opět i omezený system inventáře. REovsky tak omezený že často nevíte co byste radši vyměnili za ten herb. Ale tady se mi taky naskytl problem který jsem nijak neřešil takže nevím jestli je to dost vzácný problem a nebo to dokonce ani není problem jen jsem nepochopil mechaniky hry, ale občas když jsem otevřel inventář tak se mi nezobrazil kursor. Což je problem protože pak nebylo nijak možné vyhodit věci. (Teda aspoň si to myslím, klávesově jsem to nedokázal, možná byl způsob. Ani já tu hru nemam od A do Z proštudovanou.)

Grafika -
Opět pokrok od RE5, stále to není tak parádní, ale máme tu nějaké hezké efekty, osvětlení a další věcičky. O grafiku se tolik nezájímám takže to je asi vše k tomu.

Mechaniky hry -
Tady bych vytknul jednu věc, sice jednu ale kritickou. Hra si přímo ZAKLÁDÁ na Quick time eventech. Unikni zombie tak že budeš klikat pravé a levé tlačítko myší. Odkopni zombie tak že ve správnou dobu klikneš. Mačkej zběsile R aby si otočil páčkou á však to znáte. Ale tady je to až tak šílené použito ve všem, až je to otravné.
Skills, po kapitolách naleznete i sběratelské předměty včetně skill pointu. Což trochu zachovává replayabilitě. Sbíráte emblemy abyste si otevřeli dokumenty a figurky" hrdinů. A taky dáváte dohromady skill pointy abyste si odemkli vylepšení pro samo sebe. Klasika ale pro spoustu lidí zábavná věc.

Bonusy -
Ve hře je kromě te 30ti hodinové kampaně dokonce DALŠÍ MOŽNOST. Když nemluvím o placených DLC tak máte i po dohrání kampaně možnost si zahrát Mercenries mod

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game. The story and gameplay were good enough to lure me in.

Story:
There are 4  different campaigns in this game each with its own style. For example, Leon story has more emphasis on survival while the other two campaigns focused more on action.  All of the campaigns connect with each other in the story's timeline.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is essentially the same as resident evil 5, only this time the characters can move while aiming.  Quick time events are excessive and can get repetitive. However, quick time events can be turned off in the options.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 6 is a fantastic game, if you come into it with the right expectations.

If you expect survival horror in the vein Resident Evil is known for, you'll be sorely disappointed. Ammo is plentiful, there are no jump scares, and the majority of the combat is fast and quick, not slow and threatening. While the plot measures up to Resident Evil 6 standards of being stupidly, hilariously bad and awesome, and the tone is ominous, this game does not stick to the roots in the gameplay. It's action horror, not survival horror.

I cannot and will not hold that against the game though, because the new system is so solid. It's quick, responsive, lets the player easily keep pace with the action going on around them, and has a cover system that feels more fluid than a lot of other 3rd person shooters. The melee combat works well enough, the enemies are varied and always pose a challenge, and all of this works together with one of the more fluid co-op experiences I've ever seen.

Don't expect many people online to just drop in with you, as the PC version isn't the most well-populated Co-op place. That's not a problem though, because the game's partner AI is both invulnerable, and hyper-competent. You'll have no trouble getting through the game. And it's a good port too; better graphics (even better if you want to slap ENB or SweetFX on), and  all the quicktime events indicate the actual keys you bound, not just HIT ATTACK? OH GOD WHAT DID I BIND ATTACK TO".

If you're a fan of Resident Evil and won't mind a fast-paced shooter version of it
date: buy this now. If you see this game on sale for 20 bucks and want to know if it's worth it
recommended: it is. You'll easily get 15-20 hours of good single player out of it
hoursPlayed: plus the multiplayer modes."

reviewText:
Well, yeah, I would say this is worth playing, not the BEST resident evil game but well made holding 4 campaign modes, all with their own areas that overlap with others, a good co-op feel and system as well as a really fun score attack mode.
One of the things I really loved about this though was the sheer number of contextual actions it allows you, be it taking an ax out of a zombies head to plunge it into it's hear or taking a severed hand attacking you and throwing it into a microwave.

Honestly it isn't the resident evil we all grew up with, but that does not stop it being a good game and one I plan to play again, it looks great, sounds great and it shows that some of the people who made it actually cared a lot more then the press hate it got as soon as it came out, get it on sale, give it a go and have fun.

reviewText: I'm gonna be absolutely honest with all of you -- before I got this game, I would have told everyone in the world that it was a big, huge, slimy, stinking, rancid heap of dog ♥♥♥♥.  After playing it, however...\n\nIf you are looking for a fun co-op game with a totally over the top (hilarious) plot, funny characters, pretty solid shooting, big bosses, and a mechanic that lets you thumbs up your partner whenever he doesn't ♥♥♥♥ up, this game is actually pretty fun to play.  if you are a hardcore RE fan though, you may not be able to stomach what this series has become, but you would be missing out on what can be a pretty fun game if you can put all that aside.

reviewText: I bet if this game had a different title it would be geneorusly popular. Sadly thanks to the depressed butt hurt fans who desperately want to return to the past just like any other long running game series (aka final fantasy) the game doesn't do so well in the eyes of the public. To be honest it has the best action, best textures, graphics and the longest bunch of campaigns with so many modes then any of the other resident evil titles before it. The ability to move and shoot was long over do and to be honest people need to just accept that in life things change. So what if it's not scary enough, it sure is hell is fun. Sure some franchises should go back to their roots like Yu-Gi-Oh or Pokemon. However, Resident Evil has improved both graphically and story wise. Why would we want to return to a game setting that got a place in the guisness world records for worst voice acting in a video game? Like the annoying butt hurt fans of final fantasy who dislike where the series it going, just accept it for what it is now. So please take a chance on this game and final fantasy 15, you won't be disapointed.

reviewText:
One of my favorite titles in the third-person shooter genre.

A good example where the sum of it's parts are greater than the individual pieces.  The controls can be clunky and overcomplicated (use a gamepad), quick-time events are always a point of contention, the graphics (while very good) can be a bit underwhelming in spots, the interface is odd and takes time to familiarize yourself with, the story is completely over the top...

But the way it's all wrapped together just works so well.  It's an immense coop experience.  It's a very long experience by third person shooter standards (roughly 20-25 hours for a complete playthrough of all campaigns) and honestly I loved almost every bit of it.  Heh.  Most of these flaws" are really just a matter of getting used to change.  This isn't the Resident Evil of old
date: and convention is regularly defied.  Which isn't always a bad thing
recommended: but you'll have to adjust for it.  The tension of tip-toeing and backtracking through a mansion for hours on 10 bullets is replaced with shootouts
hoursPlayed: explosions and grandeous boss battles.  The "zombies" often have guns.\n\nIf you can manage to appreciate that this is an action game first
voteText: and Resident Evil second... go in with an open mind
helpfulPercent: and more importantly
votesHelpful: go in with a friend... you'll have a great time.  The little flaws will be almost endearing in the bigger picture.\n\nIf you can't appreciate that... odds are the issues I mentioned above could ruin it for you."

reviewText: Not a good Resident Evil game.  Not the best horror game.  But the gameplay is solid, versatile and extremely polished.  Controls are a bit complex but...you can roll in 4 directions, take cover, slide, perform melee attacks, takedowns, Fire from your backside, slide over low cover fluidily, climb up and down context sensitive areas(ladders, ledges, etc.), perform counter attacks, and maybe a few other things I'm forgetting.  So it's absurdly robust!  And you can do it with a friend!!

reviewText:
First, let's get through the negatives. Yes, the writing is mostly a joke — it resembles the movies too much, and goes nowhere interesting. The palette is pretty boring, or at least it bored me; there's too many washed out blues, reds, and purples throughout the game. The camera was jerky at times (though the initial complaints of it being too zoomed in was something I never understood). Leon is no longer funny and Helena is even worse. Some enemies reminded me too much of L4D, a game which I was not a huge fan of. Cover shooting is kind of tacked on. That's about it.

This game is still good. There's so much content here. 4 different campaigns, each with several different environments you play through. There are SO many environments in this game! There's also a ton of enemies; granted, many of them are just small variations of one another, but it's still an impressive amount overall. There's plenty of weapons, the melee system has been revamped, the inventory has been revamped... Capcom really put a lot of effort into the game. No Mercy Mercenaries is also incredible and totally blows Resident Evil 5 Mercenaries out of the water. The co-op action and content of this game more or less makes Resident Evil 5 unplayable and irrelevant now.

Too many people, mostly nostalgia-driven, played this just looking for something to complain about I think. They failed to realize all the great things it did as a result. For example, the campaign intersections — who ever brings those up? Except those were awesome and were no doubt an idea from the director Eiichiro Sasaki who also directed the Outbreak games. The intersections added a layer of immersion not seen before in games, it reminded you that other players were going through the other campaigns and thus made the story feel like it was happening in real-time. This new dimension of campaign storytelling was an ambitious improvement, apparently too ambitious because nobody even recognized how amazing it was! The combat system is also so intricately balanced and complex here, that many people end up just complaining that it's too hard; they say there isn't enough ammo in the game, or the camera is too hard to control, when these things simply weren't the case. I ranked in the top 10 in Mercenaries the first month of release prior to any camera patches, any complaints about the camera are a complete result of utter incompetence in my opinion.

Overall it's not the best Resident Evil, and it's not the best game of all time, but it was still a very good game. The hate was uncalled for. If you want to play No Mercy on PC with me feel free to hit me up, I'm down for that any day.

reviewText:
Nice Co-op TPS Action game. RE 6 keeps you in a game from start to the end. Good multiplayer modes that keeps you in a game after campaign completion for a lot of time. Good campaign and multiplayer replayability.
This game much better than RE 5, but slightly below RE 4(due to lack of puzzles plurality).

I am surprised, of what Game Press waited of this game(maybe some innovations, new gameplay features or something else...) This game was not going to follow the canons of the survivor-horror classic from the start of developing. It's just a good continuation of a Resident Evil Franchise, no more, no less...

This game is clearly deserving of assessment is not less than 8.

But I have two bad parts of this PC port:
1)a LOT OF bugs, and consoles controls(you'll see it well in the Creatures' gameplay), low customizable controls... (I think it's more likely to be fixed with a future patches in the next six months(I hope so))
2)Bad graphics and graphic customization and very low resolution of Textures.(Comparing with Resident Evil 5...)

I think for 6 months, CAPCOM could make a better PC port. But I think that they were mistreat the PC port after hearing low estimates of Game Press...

You played a cruel joke to PC players, CAPCOM...
Do not repeat this mistake with upcoming PC port of Resident Evil: Revelations...

reviewText:
~Nechce se ti číst do detailů? Přečti si Shrnutí!

Resident Evil 6/ Biohazard 6 (originalní název) je third-person akční lineární střílečka, dělaná pro dva hráče.
Začal bych kampaní, za kterou bych přidal dost bodíků. Kampaň je dlouhá a dokonce rozčleněná na 5 etap a ty etapy ještě na kapitoly. Kampaň má dokupy něco kolem 30 hodin, což je víc než dostačující.
Nalezneme zde Intro, což je, jak již název napovídá, pouze jeden level kde nás hra seznámí co a jak.

Kampaně -
Leonovu kampaň. Tato kampaň je takové vaše typické moderní Resident Evil, procházíme různé lokace, střílíme klasické zombie a sem tam potkáme něco silnějšího. U mě je tato kampaň na druhém místě ze čtyř dostupných. (nepočítám intro)

Chrisovo kampaň. Hrajeme za člena BSAA Chrise Redfielda a nebo za jeho parťáka Pierse Nivanse a snažíme se ,jako každý charakter ze hry, polapit Adu Wong a zachránit svět před hromadným Bio útokem. Tahle recenze není spoiler free takže dál k tomu nic.
Avšak kdybych měl kampaň zhodnotit tak Chrisovo je asi nejhorší, stále není špatná, ale ze všech dostupných je nejhorší.

Jakeovo kampaň. Hrajeme zde za Jakea nebo Sherry a tahle kampaň má dle mě tu nejzajímavější zápletku a i levely. Jake je imunní vůči C-Viru a Sherry má zajistit aby se v bezpečí dostal do laborek a oni mohli udělat vakcínu. Avšak Ada si to nenechá líbit a pošle nezničitelného Ustanaka který ma za každou cenu zabít Jakea a donést ho k ní. A bude se snažit fakt tvrdě. Tato kampaň je jednoznačně u mě na prvním místě.

A jako poslední tu máme kampaň Ady Wong. Která se mi zas líbí ve faktu že je dost odlišná od ostatních. Není v ní až tolik akce a v první misi se máte dokonce snažit jí projít stealth, což mě docela překvapilo na moderní Resident Evil. Ačkoliv i přesto jí mám na druhém nejhorším místě, hned za Chrisem.


Gameplay -
Jak bylo zmiňováno na začátku, toto RE si opět zahrajeme z pohledu třetí osoby. Budeme sbírat náboje do 400 typů zbraní, hledat skill pointy a taky marně koukat po Zelených rostlinách které jaksi charakter zpracuje a pak si z nich dobijí život. To taky není žádná novinka. Ačkoliv, byl zlepšen aiming systém. A jde to vidět. Znatelně se zde líp míří než v RE5. Stále to není úplně ťip ťop ale přesto ukázka zlepšení tu je.
Co se týče movementu, máme tu celkem dost tlačítek. Můžeme sprintovat, chodit pomalu, dodgovat dopředu i do stran a bůh ví co ještě. Takže tady je toho nejspíš dost.
Zároveň co mi přišlo dost zajímavé je to, že i přesto že hra používá milion tlačítek na různé akce, tak např. na reload a sbírání věcí je to samé tlačítko! Což mi ale nakonec přišlo docela pohodlné.

Ovládání -
K tomuhle mám několik věcí co říct. Je to šílené, ne tak jako ARMA ale stálé ŠÍLENÉ! Je tu milion akcí na různá tlačítka a do toho i další milion kombinací. Já osobně jsem si např. změnil přehazování itemů na  3+M3 a přeházování zbraní je klasicky M3 (kolečky u myši), takže to byla ukázka.
Zároveň tu je opět i omezený system inventáře. REovsky tak omezený že často nevíte co byste radši vyměnili za ten herb. Ale tady se mi taky naskytl problem který jsem nijak neřešil takže nevím jestli je to dost vzácný problem a nebo to dokonce ani není problem jen jsem nepochopil mechaniky hry, ale občas když jsem otevřel inventář tak se mi nezobrazil kursor. Což je problem protože pak nebylo nijak možné vyhodit věci. (Teda aspoň si to myslím, klávesově jsem to nedokázal, možná byl způsob. Ani já tu hru nemam od A do Z proštudovanou.)

Grafika -
Opět pokrok od RE5, stále to není tak parádní, ale máme tu nějaké hezké efekty, osvětlení a další věcičky. O grafiku se tolik nezájímám takže to je asi vše k tomu.

Mechaniky hry -
Tady bych vytknul jednu věc, sice jednu ale kritickou. Hra si přímo ZAKLÁDÁ na Quick time eventech. Unikni zombie tak že budeš klikat pravé a levé tlačítko myší. Odkopni zombie tak že ve správnou dobu klikneš. Mačkej zběsile R aby si otočil páčkou á však to znáte. Ale tady je to až tak šílené použito ve všem, až je to otravné.
Skills, po kapitolách naleznete i sběratelské předměty včetně skill pointu. Což trochu zachovává replayabilitě. Sbíráte emblemy abyste si otevřeli dokumenty a figurky" hrdinů. A taky dáváte dohromady skill pointy abyste si odemkli vylepšení pro samo sebe. Klasika ale pro spoustu lidí zábavná věc.

Bonusy -
Ve hře je kromě te 30ti hodinové kampaně dokonce DALŠÍ MOŽNOST. Když nemluvím o placených DLC tak máte i po dohrání kampaně možnost si zahrát Mercenries mod
date: který teda mě osobně dost baví. Je to klasický Horde mode. Zvolíte mapu

reviewText: This walks the line for me, but I'm somewhat reluctantly coming down on the side of not making a recommendation. It's a pretty good action game that looks pretty, the controls are FINALLY excellent, it has a solid length to it, the AI is improved (a bit) from RE5, and most of the game can be played in co-op. But this is not a horror game. There's nothing scary in it. At all. You'd think that would be necessary for a Resident Evil game, but Capcom unwisely disagrees. This doesn't even feel like a Resident Evil game most of the time. The plot is the worst nonsense this side of a Jill sandwich, and while it does have some replayability, I find I don't really want to play it again. There's nothing even resembling a puzzle. The music is probably the best in the series, to be honest, but that's not enough to save it.\n\nBut the reason I can't recommend this game is that it has Quick-Time Events. Screw QTE's. They ruin games for me, and you can add Resident Evil 6 to that pile.
